content: Vos SDK et API Rainbow pour concevoir vos solutions CPaaS RainbowDéveloppez vos applications en ajoutant des fonctionalités de communicationUtilisez Rainbow for Developers pour enrichir vos applications avec de la messagerie instantanée, bulles, voix et vidéo, conférence, partage de fichiers, les fonctionnalités téléphoniques des PBX et plus encore.Une nouvelle offre de souscription CPaaS est disponibleVous êtes un partenaire commercial et vous avez développé une application Rainbow que vous souhaitez vendre à vos clients? Notre nouvelle offre App Connect est faite pour vous.Découvrir cette offreRainbow for Developers, une plateforme CPaaS uniqueRainbow for Developers est la plateforme cloud simple et intuitive pour connecter les personnes, les objets et les processus métier avec des communications en temps réel et des capacités multi-tenant.Apprenez-en plus sur les Développeur et Solution Partner ProgrammesExploitez vos capacités d'innovation et votre expertise avec Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise pour développer des applications uniques qui répondent aux besoins de l'entreprise grâce au DSPP.Devenez partenaireConnectez-vous avec votre compteS'authentifier !Vous n'avez pas de compte? Inscrivez-vous!S'inscrireParlez-nous du portail Rainbow for DevelopersNous apprécions vos commentaires, faites-nous part de vos idées ou commentaires, nous les utiliserons pour améliorer notre service.Partager vos idéesSuccess storiesLa gestion réussie d'une urgence nécessite la coordination et la coopération de nombreuses parties prenantes différentes, des personnes sur place qui rencontrent l'urgence en premier lieu, au répartiteur 911 qui prend l'appel, en passant par le premier intervenant qui se présente sur les lieux. Rave et l'ALE s'engagent à briser les silos qui empêchent une communication efficace et à améliorer l'interopérabilité entre les écoles et la sécurité publique afin de créer des campus plus sûrs et de sauver des vies.Todd MillerDirecteur de l'exploitation, Rave Mobile SafetyCette nouvelle infrastructure nous a permis de simplifier le partage et l'administration de nos systèmes d'information, ainsi que de sécuriser nos deux Data Centers par la mise en place d'un plan de continuité d'activité. Nous avons pu déployer de nouveaux services tels que la visioconférence, le deskphone IP et l'IoT pour nos besoins internes et pour les besoins des utilisateurs.Jean-Luc HamelinChef des services d'infrastructure numérique, Métropole et ville de PerpignanRainbow nous a permis de rester opérationnels à tout moment. Nous avons pu répondre au besoin urgent de communications numériques en quelques jours et prendre en charge les flux de travail clés de manière transparente afin qu'ils fonctionnent indépendamment de la présence du personnel sur le site.Ralph LehrChef du département, Kreisverwaltung GermersheimEn savoir plus sur nos SDKsSDK pour CSharpCréez des applications de bureau qui connectent les personnes via un riche ensemble de services. Le SDK Rainbow pour CSharp vous fournira des discussions en direct avec les utilisateurs finaux, des conversations audio ou vidéo en "one-to-one" ou en groupe à l'aide de bulles.Vers le SDK CSharpSDK pour WebCréez des applications Web pour votre site Web qui connectent les personnes via un riche ensemble de services. Le SDK Rainbow pour le Web fournira à votre site Web existant des discussions en direct avec les utilisateurs finaux, des conversations audio ou vidéo en "one-to-one" ou en groupe à l'aide de bulles.Vers le SDK WebSDK pour AndroidEtablissez des discussions audio et vidéo entre vos utilisateurs via votre application Android. Le SDK Rainbow pour Android fournit des services Rainbow à votre application mobile, comme discuter en direct en audio ou vidéo, discuter en groupe ou échanger des fichiers.Vers le SDK AndroidSDK pour iOSEtablissez des discussions audio et vidéo entre vos utilisateurs via votre application iOS. Le SDK Rainbow pour iOS fournit des services Rainbow à votre application mobile, comme discuter en direct en audio ou vidéo, discuter en groupe ou échanger des fichiers.Vers le SDK iOSSDK pour React NativeUtilisez le SDK pour React Native pour développer des applications hybrides qui s'exécuteront à la fois sur iOS et Android. Il permettra d'intégrer rapidement des fonctionnalités de chat, de vidéo et de voix à vos applications mobiles.Vers le SDK ReactNativeSDK pour Node.jsCréez un chatbot ou surveillez les alarmes et les statistiques de vos appareils IoT. Le SDK Rainbow pour Node.js est une bibliothèque JavaScript qui se connecte à Rainbow et fournit à votre application cloud ou IoT un agent toujours actif et capable de communiquer avec les utilisateurs ou les objets.Vers le SDK NodeAPI RESTConnectez vos applications pour les tâches d'exploitation administratives telles que l'approvisionnement et la gestion des compagnies et des utilisateurs Rainbow. En utilisant les API REST Rainbow, vous pouvez connecter vos applications front-end ou backend à Rainbow pour effectue

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationRainbow's best practicesRainbow's best practices Here are some advices for helping you starting your integration with Rainbow. Follow API and SDK changes In 2021, we changed our SDK relea
content: DocumentationRainbow's best practicesRainbow's best practices Here are some advices for helping you starting your integration with Rainbow. Follow API and SDK changes In 2021, we changed our SDK release and support policy to minimize the SDK update frequency for applications running in production. We now have two version tracks for C#, Web, NodeJS, Android and iOS SDKs: LTS (Long Term Support) : This is the recommended version you should use for an application running in production. LTS versions are supported for at least six months after they have been released. STS (Short Term Support) : You can use STS versions if you need the latest evolutions that are not already available in the current LTS version. We do not recommend the usage of STS versions if you don't really need it and for applications running in production. STS versions are not supported (we do not release corrections on this track). It's a best practice to update to the current LTS supported version in order to benefit support and stay closer to the latest evolutions in term of features, security and improvments. Previous LTS versions are not supported. In the same way, it's a best practice to move away from deprecated APIs as soon as announced for using stable APIs. Integrate our SDKs before moving to production Having an autonomous process that updates your application with the latest version of one of our SDKs is not good. The reason is that sometimes, a new version of a SDK comes with some breaking changes that you should handle manually. It's not a complex task because the migration path is described in our What's new guides but if not done, your application will not work correctly. A best practice is to integrate a new version of our SDK in your integration environment and once tested, move it to your production environment. Separate Rainbow concerns When integrating one of our SDKs or our REST APIs, you will manage a lot of methods to exchange data with Rainbow, a lot of events that will trigger callbacks and consequently a lot of Rainbow data. A good practice is to group the Rainbow stuff in one or several modules that are the only ones that connect to Rainbow and not to diffuse Rainbow data models everywhere in your app (except if Rainbow is the sole source of data used). Using that pattern, you will easily be able to debug, test and mock the Rainbow part in one hand and make changes according to Rainbow SDK or API evolutions in an other hand. Learn from the console logs When opening your development tool while using the SDK for Web or Android/iOS or if you have a look to the shell terminal that launches your Node.JS SDK process, you will see a lot of messages. These messages are initiated by our SDKs and give you a lot of information on what is currently happening. It's a best practice to use these information to understand and check that what is happening is correct. Don't forget to add these information when discussing with us on the forum or with our support team. Don't loop on API or SDK methods It's a good practice when developing your application to check that you are not writing loops that call Rainbow APIs or SDK methods. If for any reasons, you made a mistake in your code, you will send a lot of requests to Rainbow that will generate extra fees. Test on few Before releasing your applications to many users, it's a good practice to test your development on few users in order to check that all interactions with Rainbow are ok. The developers sandbox platform give you this possibility to test using fake accounts and so without disturbing real users. Experiment but don't hack If you don't find a proper way to do what you want, a good practice is to use the community forum to ask for help or for supporting a new feature. Trying absolutely to find a solution may cause side effects in your application if you're not using the Rainbow methods or data as they should be used. Prevent the worst Even if we garantee an uptime of the Rainbow platform higher than 99,5%, it's a good practice to handle all the bad things that can happen. Each SDK provides a lot of events that your application can subscribe in order to be alerted in case of the connection to Rainbow is lost. Same thing when something goes wrong such as if a chat message has not been successfully sent to your recipient. Design and implement security best practices Security and data privacy are paramount for Rainbow business, as well as yours. Bring confidence and security to your customers by integrating the industry best practices on the matter. Consider these topics early in your application and infrastructure design. You can find valuable resource explaining the main category of risks and vulnerabilities for web and mobile applications on the OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project) for example: OWASP Web Top 10 OWASP Mobile Top 10 - 2016 Take care of the data, take care of your users, take care of your business. excerpt: DocumentationDeveloper's journeyDeveloper's Journey Here is a check list that lists the main actions to get your Rainbow for Developers journey off to a good start. Sign-in a free Rainbow account A Ra
content: DocumentationDeveloper's journeyDeveloper's Journey Here is a check list that lists the main actions to get your Rainbow for Developers journey off to a good start. Sign-in a free Rainbow account A Rainbow account is mandatory to sign-in to the Rainbow for Developers portal. So the first thing to do is to sign-in a Rainbow account. This is free. One of the main reasons is because if you're a Rainbow user, we will be able to contact you easily through Rainbow to support you "in live". Once you have your Rainbow account, you can log-in to the Rainbow for Developers portal. The first time you will log-in, you will have to accept the Rainbow developer agreement. Once you did it, you will become a Rainbow developer and concretely your Rainbow account will be empowered to create and manage Rainbow applications. Your journey is starting... Connect and Develop This chapter describes how to start developping applications on our Rainbow Sandbox developer platform. Download SDKs and Starter-kits Once you have your account, you can start using our SDKs and APIs. The Rainbow for Developers portal presents each SDK in a dedicated web page containing a direct access to the online documentation, a link for downloading the SDK and some samples and starter-kits that you can use for starting your development. Activate your Developer Sandbox account If this is your first time developing a Rainbow application, we encourage you to activate your Developer Sandbox account. This is a free Rainbow account to be used on the Rainbow Sandbox platform. This platform is dedicated to developers, to let them play with our API and SDK without having to disturb real users. This platform is free of charge. Creating your Developer Sandbox account can be done from the section Sandbox in the left side menu. On this dedicated page, click on CREATE YOUR SANDBOX DEVELOPER ACCOUNT. You will receive an email with your sandbox account credentials. The sandbox account status displayed in the sandbox page should show "ACTIVE". You can now connect to the sandbox platform to handle sandbox applications (see "Creating a test application" below). IMPORTANT: Please note that your sandbox credentials are not the same as your main "production" credentials. This means you have two credentials information: one for the production platform and one for the sandbox platform. Read this guide to have more information on the Developers Sandbox platform. Creating tests accounts The sandbox account cumulates different roles so you can easily test your developments. These roles are: Rainbow user and application developer so you can connect to Rainbow sandbox platform and manage applications on this platform, Company administrator: when the sandbox account is created by the system, it is linked to a personal company named "Company of <username>". The company administrator rights allow you to manage test Rainbow user accounts on the sandbox platform for testing. As an example, these Rainbow users can be used when developing a chat application for simulating users. To create and manage your test accounts on the Rainbow Developer Sandbox platform, click on the link under "To manage your tests accounts connect to". This will open a new Rainbow web client tab. Connect with you sandbox account credentials, and go to the Administration tab. In the MyCompany / Members section, you will be able to list, modify, create and delete user accounts in your sandbox company (this is possible because a sandbox account has the company administration role for the sandbox user's own company). Remark: You can also install the Rainbow CLI command line tool to manage test user accounts. Read the guide Managing Test Accounts to have more information on how to manage your tests accounts using the Rainbow CLI. Creating a test application Once you have created your sandbox tests accounts, you will need a test application too on the sandbox platform. Any user who wants to connect to Rainbow needs to be identified by his credentials and by the application credentials. The application credentials are the application id and application secret. To create or manage applications on the sandbox platform you have to connect in the Sandbox section of Rainbow for Developers using the "Connect to sandbox" option. This will open a "Connect to sandbox" login popup where you can enter your sandbox credentials. Once connected, you will be able to list, modify, create or delete applications on the sandbox platform. Remark: the applications listed in the Sandbox section of Rainbow for Developers are only sandbox applications. To manage applications for the production platform, you have to go in the Applications section of Rainbow for Developers. Remark: Alternatively, you can also use the Rainbow CLI tool to create you sandbox applications. Read the guide Managing applications to have more information on how to create your test application using the Rainbow CLI. Remark: Applications created on the sandbox platform are

excerpt: DocumentationDevelopment on SandboxDevelopment on Sandbox Our Rainbow Sandbox platform for developers is a testing environment that mimics the live Rainbow Production environment. It provides a secure
content: DocumentationDevelopment on SandboxDevelopment on Sandbox Our Rainbow Sandbox platform for developers is a testing environment that mimics the live Rainbow Production environment. It provides a secured space where you can test and develop your application without impacting any live Rainbow accounts. The Sandbox platform offers the same level of Rainbow API features as the production platform except for some Business and Enterprise grade services. By using Sandbox test accounts and their associated authentication credentials in your Rainbow application, you can test and debug without referencing any real Rainbow users and so avoid interactions with others real Rainbow users too. The next sections describe in details how to create your Developer Sandbox account and how to use it. Sandbox platform for developers vs Production platform Our Rainbow Sandbox platform for developers is a Rainbow environment similar to the Rainbow Production platform that can be used when developing your application. Only developers are allowed to access to this Sandbox platform. The aim of that platform is to let you discover and try our Rainbow SDKs and APIs without disturbing real users on the production platform. That's why this platform is independent of the Rainbow Production platform. So you can't interact with real users and consequently make mistake on your existing data, contacts, etc... On that platform, you can create as many tests accounts as you want. This is useful if you want to develop and test your chat or collaboration use cases. Free of charge The Rainbow Sandbox for developers is "free of charge" in order to let you familiarize with Rainbow. When you're using this platform to develop your application, there is no accrued charge when calling Rainbow API or services. The Rainbow Sandbox platform for developers may limit the usage of each API per day for security and performance reason. Developing on Rainbow Sandbox platform for developers The following sections describe how to register and use your Sandbox developer account and how to create and connect your application to the Rainbow Sandbow platform for developers. Activating your Sandbox developer account For developing and testing your application with Rainbow using our Developers Sandbox platform, you need first to activate your sandbox account. Here is the procedure: StepDescription Sign-in to Rainbow for DevelopersThe first step is to sign-in to the Rainbow for Developers login page with your Rainbow credentials. Activate your Sandbox accountFrom the Sandbox section located in the left side menu, click on Create your sandbox button.This action will create your account on the Sandbox platform. Get your credentialsOnce activated, you will receive an email containing your Rainbow credentials for connecting to the Sandbox platform. You have now activated your sandbox account. Creating your test accounts When you create your Rainbow sandbox account, a company is created with the name "Company of <username>". The Rainbow sandbox account is member and administrator of this personal company. Test accounts can be created in this company. These will be visible only inside the company itself. There are two options to create and manage test accounts on the Sandbox platform: The easiest way is to connect to the Rainbow sanbox web client (the link can be found in the Sandbox page of Rainbow for Developers). You have to connect to the Rainbow sandbox web client using your sandbox credentials. Then, click on the "Administration" tab, then "MyCompany" / "Members". The other option to manage test accounts on the Sandbox platform is using the Rainbow CLI command line tool: StepDescription Install the Rainbow CLIThe first step is to install our Rainbow CLI application for connecting to the Sandbox platform for developers.You need to install Node.JS and then the Rainbow CLI package. Connect the Rainbow CLILaunch the command rbw configure to configure your Rainbow CLI application with the sandbox credentials received by email.Launch the command rbw login to connect to the Rainbow Sandbox platform for developers. Create your test accountsOnce connected, to create test accounts, launch the command rbw create user like described in the guide Managing test accounts to create a test account Use your tests accountsYou can use or modify the accounts created either by using the Rainbow CLI application (use the command rbw commands to have the full list of available commands) or by using the Rainbow sandbox web client. Your test accounts are now ready. Now, you need to register an application to connect to Rainbow. Creating your application You must have an application identifier and secret key to identify your application on the Rainbow Sandbox platform for developers like on the Rainbow Production platform. There are two ways to create and manage your applications on the Rainbow Sandbox platform. The easiest way is to use the Rainbow for Developers Sandbox section. You need to click th

excerpt: DocumentationLimitsLimits The following table lists the limits that can apply to Rainbow services. Limits are grouped by theme. These limits could be updated depending on the Rainbow platform evolutio
content: DocumentationLimitsLimits The following table lists the limits that can apply to Rainbow services. Limits are grouped by theme. These limits could be updated depending on the Rainbow platform evolutions. User and profile LimitValuesDetails Max connections per user5Same user account can be connected to Rainbow up to 5x (several resources) at the same time (ie: using several devices). Connecting more resources will disconnect existing ones. Max size of user's avatar4 MoThe maximum size of the user's avatar that can be uploaded. Companies LimitValuesDetails Max administrator accounts per company60The maximum number of users having administrator rights (such as company_admin) in a company. Max custom data size per company5 KoThe maximum size of the custom data that can be attached to a company. Max size of company's avatar4 MoThe maximum size of the company's avatar that can be uploaded. Max size of company's banner10 MoThe maximum size of the company's banner that can be uploaded. Bubbles LimitValuesDetails Max users per bubble5000Number of users that can be part of a bubble. Once reached, remaining invitations will be refused for users joining the bubble. Max active bubbles created per user1000Number of actives bubbles that can be created by a user at a time. A user can create more than 1000 bubbles only if he's owning less than 1000 actives bubbles.Archived owned bubbles are not taken into account. Max active bubbles joined per user200Number of bubbles that can be join by a user at a time. When joined, bubbles become actives and the user is notificed about incoming messages. Max custom data size per bubble80 KoThe maximum size of the custom data that can be attached to a bubble. Max size of bubble's avatar4 MoThe maximum size of the bubble' avatar that can be uploaded. Channels LimitValuesDetails Max items saved per channel100When connecting to Rainbow, only the last 100 items could be retrieved from a channel. Default value is 30. Max size of channel's notification56 koThe maximum size of the channel's content which includes the title, the message, the url and any other extran content. Max size of channel's avatar4 MoThe maximum size of the channel's avatar that can be uploaded. Files LimitValuesDetails Max quota per user1 GoNumber of Go a user can store on Rainbow. Depends today on user profile only. Max size per file100 MoMaximum size of a file that can be shared in Rainbow Groups LimitValuesDetails Max users per group500Number of users that can be added to a group Max groups per user50Number of groups a user can create Guests (CPaaS role) LimitValuesDetails Max active guests per company1000Number of active guests accounts that can exist at a timeExisting expired guest accounts are not taken into account. Max time to live per guest172800 sThe maximum validity duration of a guest account (ie: 2 days). When expired, a guest account can't connect to Rainbow. If not set, time to live is set by default to 172800. Instant Messages LimitValuesDetails Max message size1 KoMaximum size of a chat message (content) that can be sent through Rainbow. Longer messages have to be split. excerpt: DocumentationDeployment on ProductionDeployment on Production Preambule Once you have developped your application on the Sandbox platform, you need to deploy it on the Rainbow production platform to l
content: DocumentationDeployment on ProductionDeployment on Production Preambule Once you have developped your application on the Sandbox platform, you need to deploy it on the Rainbow production platform to let your real users connect and use it. This guide will help you to understand how to adapt your application for working with real users and for deploying it on Production platform. Steps Going to Rainbow production platform implies some modifications and actions to do. Here is the list of actions to do. The next sections will describe in details the different tasks needed to migrate your application. Register an application for production Up to now, you have an application that runs on the Sandbox platform. To run the application on the production platform, you need to use the Rainbow for Developers portal. Using the Rainbow for Developers portal, you need to obtain an application Id and a secret key that work on the Rainbow production platform. These information are mandatory for authorizing your application to connect to our Rainbow production platform. Do the following: Log-in to the Rainbow for Developers portal using your Rainbow user account. Be careful to not use your Sandbox account. On the left menu, select the option Applications Click on the button Create a new application. Fill the application creation wizard form (Application name, Type, Activity) Click the Create button The newly created application identifier and secret key are displayed. You can copy them using the buttons on the right of each field. To edit the application properties, locate the application in the applications table and click the edit button. Your application is not yet deployed. Deployment on the Production Platform To deploy your application on the Rainbow production platform, follow these steps: Ensure you have added a valid payment method for Pay As You Go offer applications. Visit the Billing section in the Rainbow for Developers portal, click Add a new card, provide your credit card information, and save it. You can also set up SEPA payment if preferred. For Pay As You Go offer applications: Your application will be automatically deployed upon completing the above steps, and it will become immediately accessible to your users. For Business and App Connect offer applications: Visit the Applications page in the Rainbow for Developers portal and click the deploy button. The application state will change to IN_DEPLOYMENT. Please note that in the case of Business and App Connect offers, the deployment must be validated by ALE before transitioning to the RUNNING state. Adapt your application To connect to the Rainbow production platform, adapt the application code as described: UsingTask to do Rainbow SDK for AndroidYou need to switch the value of the 3rd parameter of the API signin() from sandbox.openrainbow.com to openrainbow.com. Rainbow SDK for iOSYou need to use the connect() method. Rainbow SDK for CSharpYou need to switch the value of the 1st parameter of the API SetHostInfo() from sandbox.openrainbow.com to openrainbow.com. Rainbow SDK for WebYou need to replace the API signin() by the API signinOnRainbowOfficial(). Rainbow SDK for Node.JSYou need to switch the value of the parameter host in your configuration file from sandbox.openrainbow.com to openrainbow.com. REST APIYou need to switch the host used in your request from sandbox.openrainbow.com to openrainbow.com. Rainbow CLIIf you need to use the Rainbow CLI, you have to add the parameter --host openrainbow.com to the command rbw login or to launch the command rbw configure And secondly, you need to use the right application ID and secret key from the production platform instead of the ones from the Sandbox platform.Depending on your application, do the following: UsingTask to do Rainbow SDK for AndroidYou need to replace the value of the parameters applicationId, secretKey of the API initialize() with your application information. Rainbow SDK for iOSYou need to add the appID and appSecret in application delegates method application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions. Rainbow SDK for CSharpYou need to replace the value of the parameters applicationID, applicationSecretKey of the API SetApplicationInfo() with your application information. Rainbow SDK for WebYou need to replace the value of the parameters strApplicationID, strApplicationSecret of the API initialize() with your application information. Rainbow SDK for Node.JSYou need to replace the value of the appID, appSecret in your configuration file with your application information. REST APIYou need to update the header x-rainbow-app-auth with your application information. Protect your users and data from unexpected interactions This step is mandatory if you want to create new Rainbow accounts in your application (backend or frontend). If you already own a Rainbow account with company_admin right or if your application reuse existing Rainbow accounts only, you can go to the next paragraph. In order to create new Rainb

excerpt: DocumentationGetting startedGetting started Welcome to our built with passion Rainbow for Developers ! Here is the place where you can find all the documentation and materials regarding the different
content: DocumentationGetting startedGetting started Welcome to our built with passion Rainbow for Developers ! Here is the place where you can find all the documentation and materials regarding the different ways to integrate with ALE Rainbow using our Rainbow SDKs and APIs. From a client side integration through a web page or a mobile application to a server side integration, the Rainbow for Developers offers different solutions depending on your needs. Take time to read this documentation and have fun playing with Rainbow ! How to read this documentation We grouped together all the documentation around Rainbow SDKs and APIs in that place. You're reading this first guide which is in fact a sum-up of what you can expect from our Rainbow CPaaS platform. From the left menu, you can find a lot of guides, each focusing on a key concept or a group of API. We organized this menu like that: In the Basics section, you will find all the guides to start from the beginning such as the Prerequisites, the developer's journey road book that will give you step by step the actions to do for using our Rainbow services. If you don't understand some Rainbow 'words', have a look to our glossary. The Advanced guides section will give you the keys to go deeper with Rainbow and use the platform at 150%. All concepts such as the privacy rules or the way core concepts works and how to deploy on production. Then, each SDK has 2 separates sections: One giving a complete API documentation and the other offering several guides to explain in details how to use our SDK and API to do things such as sending a chat message to a user, calling someone in video, etc... Don't miss the what's new guide that sums-up the list of changes in each new release of SDK and APIs. Our C#, Web, NodeJS, Android and iOS SDKs follow the LTS / STS release policy. Both LTS (Long Term Support) and STS (Short Term Support) documentations are available. LTS documentation will show you all the features contained in the current LTS version. STS documentation will show you latest features that are not yet available in LTS version. By default, the documentation displayed for these SDKs is the LTS version documentation. If you need to read the STS version documentation, you can switch the documentation version from your profile page once logged in. Please read LTS SDK support policy and versions for all details about this new support policy. Our CPaaS platform Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow for Developers is an open platform as a service (CPaaS) with a set of APIs allowing you to integrate Rainbow's powerful collaboration tools into your existing in-house applications and business processes. Rainbow brings rich feature capabilities, like contact management, presence, chat, audio/video call, screen and file sharing. In addition to these features, Rainbow takes a hybrid cloud approach, integrating with Alcatel-Lucent OXO Connect and OmniPCX Enterprise, as well as non-ALE PBXs and so providing APIs to control your phone device. Rainbow Hub cloud PBX are also supported. Built to digitalize your business The Rainbow for Developers makes it easy your digital transformation by providing you APIs, documentation and support that let you build applications that connect people and transform the way they work. For example, a school district can take advantage of a broadcast lockdown and response application in a crisis, a hotel can leverage the Rainbow services integrated into their customer loyalty program application, or a bank can use Rainbow to integrate messaging and notifications over their customer relationship applications. Tailored to your needs The Rainbow for Developers offers several SDKs, APIs, libraries and tools that are available on a lot of platforms and systems to match with your ecosystem. EnvironmentsSDKsAPIsEvent PipeToolsLibraries & Others DesktopRainbow Web SDK or Rainbow SDK for CSharpREST APIXMPP-Starter-kits and samples WebRainbow Web SDKREST APIXMPP-Starter-kits and samples Server & BotsRainbow SDK for Node.JSREST APIXMPP or S2SRainbow CLIStarter-kits, Chatbot library, Node-Red library and samples Server & BotsRainbow SDK for CSharpREST APIXMPP or S2S-Starter-kits and samples iOSRainbow SDK for iOS or Rainbow SDK for CSharp or Rainbow SDK for ReactNativeREST APIXMPP-Starter-kits and samples AndroidRainbow SDK for Android or Rainbow SDK for CSharp or Rainbow SDK for ReactNativeREST APIXMPP-Starter-kits and samples Here is a quick summary of what you can expect from each: Rainbow Web SDK: This SDK works in all modern browsers and can be integrated in your Web applications or Web site. This SDK can be used with any existing JavaScript framework like ReactJS, AngularJS or JQuery. Additionnaly, this SDK can be used into a native application based on a Web view (for example ElectronJS, Microsoft WebView2 or Qt). This SDK can be used to build client side communication and collaboration application based on chat and audio& video, etc... Rainbow SDK for Node.JS: This

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationGlossaryGlossary The list below defines some of the basic terminology of the Rainbow for Developers and Rainbow. If you are new to Rainbow or have any question regarding Rainbow usage, yo
content: DocumentationGlossaryGlossary The list below defines some of the basic terminology of the Rainbow for Developers and Rainbow. If you are new to Rainbow or have any question regarding Rainbow usage, you can go to the Rainbow Help Center. Admin This represents an administrative role in Rainbow. Users having an admin role can manage a company (for example company_admin role) or an organization ( E.g. org_admin) Availability The availability represents all the information you share with your contacts regarding how they can reach you. The availability contains your application and phone presence and additionally your calendar presence information. Bubble A bubble is a workspace designed for real time collaboration between Rainbow users. Bubble members can be organizer or member. They can chat, share files, start audio or video conferences, share their screens,... You can find more information about Rainbow bubbles usage on the Rainbow Help Center: Bubbles. Call A call is an audio only or audio and video interaction between two or more users. A call can be a CTI (Computer Telephony Integration) based call, a webRTC based call or a mixed CTI and webRTC call. A call can contain an additional application or screen sharing leg. A call always takes place into a conversation. Channel A channel is a Rainbow feature which represents a mass notification medium for sending information to a large number of users (several thousands in one time). More about Rainbow Channels on the Rainbow Help Center: Channels. Company Each user in Rainbow belongs to a company. When creating your Rainbow account, you belongs to the default Rainbow company. Then you can join an existing company to collaborate with your colleagues or create your own company. More information about Rainbow Companies on the Rainbow Help Center: What is a Rainbow Company? Contacts Contacts are Rainbow users that are in your network. More information here: How to add someone to my contacts Conversation A conversation represents the history of exchanges between you and another Rainbow user. This is all the interactions you had (i.e. calls, instant messages, files shared) and that you can retreive. A conversion is persistent. At any time, you could retrieve older interactions you did with someone. Deployed application A deployed application is a third party application that has been granted to connect to the Rainbow production platform. Developer This is a specific role a Rainbow user gains when registering to the Rainbow for Developers portal. This role is needed to create and manage third party applications. Developer Sandbox account This is a specific Rainbow account you have to use to connect to the Rainbow Developers sandbox platform for managing your Sandbox test accounts. Developer sandbox account credentials are different from the main Rainbow account credentials used to connect to the production platform. Instant messaging Instant Messaging is a Rainbow feature which allows to send and receive messages based on text, emoji, files and images. File sharing The file sharing is a Rainbow feature allowing users to share files. More information can be found here How to manage my Rainbow sharing Group Contacts in Rainbow can be gathered by defining groups. Groups allow to categorize and organize your list of contacts. Network This is the list of contacts with whom you are sharing mutually your availability: They see your availability, you see their availability. Organization An organization is a set of companies where users can see each other and collaborate. Presence The presence is a status in Rainbow that helps your contacts understanding if you can or not be reached at a time. More information can be found here: What does my contacts status mean. Privacy The privacy is a security mechanism that exists in Rainbow to protect your personal information from being accessible by other Rainbow users and to avoid unexpected interaction with Rainbow users that are out of your circle of activity (company or organization). Production platform This is the Rainbow platform where you are connected when using the AL-Enterprise Rainbow applications. Profile A profile (or a subscription) is a list of features a user can subscribe for. Several profiles exist in Rainbow: Essential, Business, Enterprise. By default, a user has the Essential profile. Third-party applications (CPaaS) overide the user profile to offer more. Push notifications The push notifications is the possibility for your mobile application to receive notifications from Rainbow when in background. Rainbow guest Represents a guest user in Rainbow. This is a restricted role a user can have (often associated to anonymous user) dedicated to third-party applications (CPaaS) and with a limited duration of life. Note: A Rainbow guest can't connect to a Rainbow application provided by AL-Enterprise. Rainbow user Represents a user in Rainbow. This is the default role you have when joining Rainbow. A Rainbow user can acces

excerpt: DocumentationLTS SDK support policy & versionsLTS SDK Support policy and versions This guide lists the current supported versions of each SDKs and explains the different kind of versions. The new LTS
content: DocumentationLTS SDK support policy & versionsLTS SDK Support policy and versions This guide lists the current supported versions of each SDKs and explains the different kind of versions. The new LTS SDK support policy applies to Web, NodeJS, C#, Android and iOS SDKs. It does not apply to ReactNative SDK for now as this SDK is still being developed. The new LTS rules do not apply to REST APIs. Supported versions Rules There are two version release tracks: LTS (Long Term Support): these are the SDK versions you should use if you want a stable version for a production use that is guaranteed to be supported for a minimum pre-defined time period, STS (Short Term Support): these are up-to-date SDK versions containing latest features, potentially unstable. As a developer using Rainbow SDKs for your applications, LTS versions are the way to go except if you need latest Rainbow features not already integrated in the LTS version. Versioning The version number of an SDK will show immediately if this is an STS, LTS beta or LTS version: STS versions will have no suffix, Beta LTS versions will have a -ltsbeta suffix. LTS versions will have a -lts suffix. LTS in details We release LTS versions that we consider stable. As software developers, you know that code modification can accidentally introduce bugs or unwanted behavior. That is why the basic rule is that an LTS version never receives new features and receives only fixes considered as critical. Before releasing a new LTS version we will release an LTS beta version. This version will contain all features of the LTS release version. Support duration: LTS version is supported for at least the time period that was announced when this version has been released. The LTS version support ends one month after the next LTS version is released. The previous LTS version is then deprecated. No support will be delivered for deprecated LTS versions. Update to the currently supported LTS version is required. If an issue is found in a deprecated LTS version, the SDK must be first updated to the currently supported LTS version. Bug fixes: If a major or critical issue is discovered in the LTS version a fixed LTS version is released. Even if the non-fixed LTS version continues to be supported it is highly recommended to update to the fixed LTS. At any time, there is only one fixed LTS version: this fixed LTS version cumulates all fixes since initial LTS version was released. This means there is no more than two LTS supported versions at a time: non-fixed LTS, fixed LTS (the latest containing all fixes found). Breaking changes: When a new LTS version is released, it can bring breaking changes (even if we try to avoid them). This means that when updating from a previous LTS, code change can be required in your application. Migration of the code will be described in the LTS release note. STS in details STS version are released on a frequent basis. These versions contains latest features and bug fixes. Support duration: STS versions are supported in a best effort mode until the next STS version is released. This means issues can be posted on our Community Forum. We will do our best to handle them. If a fix is needed, it will be available in the next STS version. Breaking changes: We try to limit breaking compatibility between versions but this can happen in the STS release track. We will document these changes in STS release notes. Beta phase: STS releases are to be considered as next LTS development versions (these can be seen as next LTS alpha versions). They contain features that will be available in the future LTS version. During the STS release track, we will qualify an STS release as "LTS beta". This means we will freeze features and focus on bug fixes until quality level is sufficient to release next LTS version. SDK Documentation The SDK documentation is available on the Rainbow for Developers. The documentation for the latest Long Term Support and Short Term Support versions are available. Documentation for previous versions are not available. For accessing to STS documentation, authentication and being registered as developer is required. In menu Profile you can select documentation to display. The selection is global to all SDKs (for example if you select LTS, you will read LTS documentation for all SDKs). There can be cases where only one version of the documentation is available: For example, when a new LTS version is active and no new STS version has been released since. If the user selects 'STS', a page will be displayed explaining there is currently no STS documentation available for this SDK. 'LTS' documentation will be available for the active LTS SDK version. The global documentation selector has two choices: LTS for the currently active Long Term Support SDK documentation STS / LTS Beta for the currently active Short Term Support SDK documentation or the currently active LTS Beta SDK documentation. As explained before, an STS version can be qualified as LTS Beta when it

excerpt: DocumentationCore conceptsRainbow core concepts Preambule To be able to develop your application that connects to Rainbow, you need to have in mind some key concepts. These concepts are in the core of
content: DocumentationCore conceptsRainbow core concepts Preambule To be able to develop your application that connects to Rainbow, you need to have in mind some key concepts. These concepts are in the core of Rainbow and called pillars. Knowing them, will help you understanding how Rainbow works and what are the rules behind. In Rainbow, there are 4 pillars or concepts: The concept of Entity The concept of Membership The concept of Relation The concept of Right This guide describes these pillars in details and illustrates how and why Rainbow is called the relationship machine. Rainbow entity An entity is something or someone that can be identified in Rainbow. Entities can be various and not only address users. Things like an iot device or a PBX are entities too. Each entity has an unique identity. The identity is the way an entity is identified and distinguished from others. An identity contains various information like a name, an avatar, an id... Information are different depending on the entity (ie: users, sites...). Each identity share a important information called the id. This identifier is the main information to interact with an entity. Using this identifier, you're are able to call Rainbow API for getting the associated vcard of this entity (depending the privacy rules - see next paragraphes) and to communicate with him. In fact, as Rainbow uses an XMPP engine for communicating in live between entities, there is always a second identifier called the jid that is used in association with the id. Internally, this is the jid that is used when for example a user wants to contact an other user in live. But both always exist. The id is the key information to use to identify a Rainbow entity. Rainbow membership The membership is a concept associated to companies, sites and organizations: A company is used to define affiliations for users. Like other entity, a company has an id and a lot of others information like a logo, a slogan that can be used to promote and reinforce its identity. And by consequences all entities belonging to this company will benefit from these information. A site can be used to associate systems inside a company. An organization groups companies inside a unique set to define specific affiliations. In Rainbow, each 'living' entity has a membership. For example, if you're a single user, by default you belong to a virtual company called 'Rainbow'. This membership defines the limits of the interactions entities can have together. Concretely, membership is based on the principle of visibility. The visibility is the way a company, an organization, a user and so any entity is visible from an other entity. Visibility can be public or private. In some words, if an entity is public, the entity can be found in the search field using a Rainbow client. If entity is private, it is private and so can't be found. The last thing to understand regarding on the membership is that information of entities is protected by privacy rules. Imagine that someone who has a private visibility calls someone who is public. The user in the public company will only have access to a minimal set of information of the private user. Information, like the loginEmail will not be available. You will access only to information that let you distinguishing the user (ie. name, photo, company). You can find additionnal information on the visibility by reading the guide Visibility and privacy rules. Rainbow relation A relation in Rainbow is how two entities "keep in touch" and so can quickly initiate a new interaction or continue an existing one together. Rainbow relations can be spontaneous when searching for someone and initiating an audio call, long-term when reopening and interacting again in chat or webRTC with a user, or privileged when the entity you contact is in your network. The type of relation you have with other Rainbow entities is very important because depending on it, you can or not have access to the entity availability information. The availability is all information you can share regarding your activity. At this time of writing, the availability is composed of Your presence activity: Are you online, dnd, away, in a video call ? Your business phone activity: Are you engaging in an audio call or not ? Your calendar activity: Are you in a meeting, out of office ? Until when ? You availability is only shared when you have a privileged relation with your recipient. Privileged relation needs an acknowledgment from your recipient, so you need to ask him by sending him an invitation to be in his network. If your recipient accepts, you will be in his network and he will be in your network. You have now a new privileged relation with a user. Be careful, it's not because your recipient is in your network that he has access to your network's contact. Being in the network of someone only allows to access to his availability. A privileged relation can be done with someone that is in the same company as well as with someone that is i

excerpt: DocumentationREST API and SDK stability policiesRainbow REST APIs and SDKs stability and compatibility policies This document describes how ALE International supports and deprecates legacy Rainbow RES
content: DocumentationREST API and SDK stability policiesRainbow REST APIs and SDKs stability and compatibility policies This document describes how ALE International supports and deprecates legacy Rainbow REST APIs, Rainbow SDKs, Rainbow CLI tool and Rainbow open-source libraries published to give developers time to transition to the latest version or at least a compatible one. Rainbow REST APIs policies The following policies rules apply to all Rainbow REST APIs published in the Rainbow for Developers platform. Rainbow REST APIs compatibility policy Wherever possible, Rainbow REST API resources and their representations (i.e. parameters sent and received) will be maintained in a backwards compatible manner. This means that Rainbow REST APIs are backwards compatible: A program written against one version of that API will continue to work the same way, without modification, against future versions of the API. If it is necessary to change an API resource or representation in a way that is not backwards compatible (breaking change), a new resource will be created using the new representation, and the old resource will be maintained in accordance with the deprecation policy, described at the end of this document. Rainbow REST APIs stability policy Rainbow REST APIs fulfill the following stability rule: An existing resource and his representation will continue to exist with the same meaning in future versions. This means: The meaning of HTTP response codes can be trusted. Each API may return several HTTP response codes but these codes once defined never change. No new HTTP response codes are introduced in existing API once published. A resource may support additional query parameters in future versions but they will not be mandatory. The absence of a value or a default value (as appropriate) will maintain prior behavior. If a resource accepts a representation (e.g. via POST or PUT), it will continue to accept the same representation in future versions. Additional properties that are recognized in a resource will not be mandatory, and the default value assumed in their absence will be chosen to maintain the previous meaning of the resource. Representations based on media type "Application/JSON" have additional stability guarantees such as: If a property exists in a JSON object returned by the REST API, it will continue to be returned with the same name, and the same value type (i.e. String, number, array or object). If a property has a primitive type and the APIs documentation does not explicitly limit its possible values, clients must not assume the values are constrained to a particular set of possible responses. If a property of an object is not explicitly declared as mandatory in the API, clients must not assume it will be present. New properties may be added to a representation at any time, but a new property must not alter the meaning of an existing property. If a property of an object is a URI, then the resource identified by that URI must maintain the same compatibility guarantee. In some specific cases, the behavior of a Rainbow REST APIs may change without explicit deprecation period if the existing behavior is incorrect or constitutes a security or privacy vulnerability. In that cases, the changelog will describe the issue and a possible workaround if exists. Rainbow REST APIs having incorrect resources or representations may be changed to fulfill REST architecture requirements. For example, in case of APIs with content type "Application/JSON", the parameters names and values may be modified if they are considered as incorrect (e.g. API that returns 'null' instead of an empty array when returning an empty list of users). This is considered as bug and will be corrected as soon as possible. Rainbow REST APIs that constitute a security or privacy vulnerability may be blocked resulting in an HTTP 404 not found when calling these APIs. That case may be temporary. Rainbow REST APIs resource/rate limits and paging policy Resource rate limits, if any, and the default and maximum sizes of paged data are not considered part of the APIs and may change without explicit deprecation period and policy. For example, an API can be changed to return by default only the 30 first results instead of the 100 first one to optimize bandwidth consumption. Resource rate limits and default and maximum sizes of paged data are described in the APIs documentation published on the Rainbow for Developers for all APIs concerned. When changed, the APIs documentation will be updated and the changelog will summarize those changes. See the deprecation policy chapter. Rainbow SDKs and Rainbow CLI tool policies The following policies rules apply to all Rainbow SDKs published in the Rainbow for Developers platform (i.e. SDK for Web, SDK for Node.JS, SDK for C#, SDK for Android, SDK for iOS and SDK for ReactNative) and for the Rainbow CLI tool. Rainbow SDKs and Rainbow CLI tool compatibility policy Wherever possible, Rainbow SDKs and the Rainbow CLI

excerpt: DocumentationSupport and contributions guidesSupport and contributions guides This guide describes how you can find help when developing on Rainbow and how you can contribute to help us delivering bet
content: DocumentationSupport and contributions guidesSupport and contributions guides This guide describes how you can find help when developing on Rainbow and how you can contribute to help us delivering better software. Support Depending on your need, here is how you can be supported. Need support when developing If you have questions on how to use our SDKs or APIs, use our developer's community forums to post your requests in order to share the answers to all developers. A good practice is to : Give us the context: Which API or SDK you didn't succeed to use. On which platform, etc... Explain you case: Give you some details on what you want to do. Add an extract of your existing code: Give a a code snippet of the part of code that don't work. Need support when finding an issue Depending the type of Rainbow SDK version used by your application (either STS or LTS), the support path is different: LTS is our stable version stream meaning we provide official support for these versions, STS is our unstable version stream, providing latest features, we provide limited support for these version. Refer to SDK Supported Versions for details about our Rainbow SDK support policy. Issue found in a Rainbow SDK STS version If you think you found an issue in a Rainbow SDK STS version: verify you use the currently released Rainbow SDK STS version. If this is not the case, update to the current STS version and check if issue still exists, gather the information listed in the Required information for a suspected issue paragraph below and every detail that is susceptible to ease investigation of the issue, post the suspected issue description and information to our Developer's Community Forum. Our team of experts will do their best to analyze and answer to your post. If the issue if confirmed, a fix will be included in a future STS version. Issue found in a Rainbow SDK LTS version If you think you found an issue in a Rainbow SDK LTS version: verify you use the officially supported Rainbow SDK LTS version. If this is not the case, update to the current LTS version and check if issue still exists, gather the information listed in the Required information for a suspected issue paragraph below and every detail that is susceptible to ease investigation of the issue, contact our ALE Support Team: by email support@openrainbow.com, with Rainbow by sending a message to our bot Emily. After a first analysis, a ticket will be opened and an answer will be provided in a short delay. If a fix is needed, an update of the current LTS version including the fix will be released. Required information for a suspected issue You will need to give us some additionnal information about the problem encountered: The context of the issue, with some information on your use case and your environment. The operation done which is the API or SDK method you are calling with a little snippet of your code that can reproduce the issue. The result observed generated by the SDK or API. Here is a summary of information to add to your ticket to help us understanding and fixing the issue. SDK or API usedContext of the issueOperation doneResult observed SDK Web- Version of SDK used- Browser used and version- Operating System and version- SDK method called- Code snippet- SDK logs- Date and time when the problem occurs- Complete stack trace in case of crash SDK iOSSDK AndroidSDK CSharp- Version of SDK used- SDK method called- Code snippet- SDK logs- Date and time when the problem occurs- Complete stack trace in case of crash SDK ReactNative- Version of SDK used- Operating System version- SDK method called- Code snippet- SDK logs- Date and time when the problem occurs SDK Node.JS- Version of SDK used- Node.JS version- Operating System and version- SDK method called- Code snippet- SDK logs (from console or files)- Date and time when the problem occurs- Complete stack trace in case of crash REST API- Operating System and version- Language used- API used- Full HTTPS request URL including parameters and headers - Full HTTPS response message Suggest new features If your want to suggest new APIs or new features that are missing in our SDKs, post your request directly to our developer's community forums. Contribution If you want to contribute, here is how to do. Contribute to the community forum You can contribute by answering questions on the developers community forum. Contribute to our open source libraries If you want to propose a change in one of our open-source projects on Github, you have to: Leave a comment stating your intention on Github. If we approve, you can do the modification in the code and send us a pull request. We will review the change and merge it as soon as possible. Additional contributions You made a crazy library related to Rainbow. Don't hesitate to send us a link. We will populate a specific page with the links to all of your contributions. Interested in Understanding SDK supported versions Understanding REST API and SDK stability policies Discovering Rainb

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationUsers authenticationUsers authentication Dealing with users authentication is always an important part of your development. It should be done carefully to avoid any security issue. This g
content: DocumentationUsers authenticationUsers authentication Dealing with users authentication is always an important part of your development. It should be done carefully to avoid any security issue. This guide will explain in details: The kind of Rainbow applications you can build How to authenticate your users for each kind of applications Best practices to secure your secret key and to protect Rainbow users data. Kinds of applications There are four kind of applications that exist: Rainbow applications: We call Rainbow applications the applications delivered by ALE International. These applications are out of the scope of this guide. Rainbow sibling applications: We call Rainbow sibling applications or just Rainbow siblings, any application that asks the user to log-in with his Rainbow credential. Each time you are building this kind of application which can be a connector, an extension or a Rainbow plugin that allows to access your Rainbow account and data in order to leverage your Rainbow experience. These applications augment the Rainbow features and integration with others platforms. Rainbow sibling services: We call Rainbow sibling services, any backend application that either dialogs with existing Rainbow users such as a bot or automates provisionning or management of Rainbow accounts such a business process connected to Rainbow that creates new Rainbow accounts. Rainbow third party applications: All others applications are called Rainbow third party applications. Theses applications have already an authentication mechanism offered by the third party platform (ie: your application and platform). In that case, your application will use Rainbow to offer new services "as if they have been developped" by you. Your application consumes Rainbow as a service. Note: If you don't know the kind of application you are building, ask you if your application can interact with existing Rainbow users. If yes, you are probably developing a Rainbow sibling application or service. If you don't want any interaction from Rainbow users because your application is dedicated to your own users with user profiles managed by your platform, you are building a Rainbow third party application. SUM-UP Kind of applicationsDetails Rainbow siblingsRainbow users connect using their Rainbow accounts in these applications.Interactions with Rainbow users using Rainbow applications or other Rainbow sibling applications could occur and have to be managed.These applications access your Rainbow identity and all the data you generated on Rainbow. You can generate new Rainbow data from these applications. Rainbow siblings servicesThese services are running on a backend infrastructure that is connected to Rainbow.Interactions with Rainbow users using Rainbow applications or other Rainbow sibling applications could occur and have to be managed.Depending on the level of rights, the Rainbow account used to provide the service can access or not to the profile of Rainbow users and manage them. These applications have no access to users data. Rainbow Third partyUsers of these applications are existing users of a third party application. These users are not aware of Rainbow and so Rainbow credentials are not known by them. They log-in using their third party credentials and receive a token on behalf the Rainbow users to be able to make requests to Rainbow.These applications create new Rainbow users. Interactions with Rainbow applications, Rainbow sibling applications, Rainbow sibling services or any other not managed third party applications should not happen to avoid unexpected behavior. Authentication methods The following points are good practices for securing your application and the data of your users. You should follow them carefully when in production. For development on the Sandbox platform, you can work without them. For Rainbow sibling applications Authentication method offered for Rainbow sibling applications is based on using a Basic Authentication from the application with the Rainbow credentials of the users. Rainbow SDK for C#, Rainbow SDK for Web and Rainbow SDK for NodeJS support OAuth2 authentication mecanism in addition to basic authentication. For Rainbow sibling services As mentionned, Rainbow sibling services work on a backend that can be hosted on our own datacenter, on a cloud hosting specialist or by us. Rainbow accounts used by these backend services can authenticate directly to Rainbow either using the Rainbow Authentication REST API provided or the SDK for Node.JS if permitted by the backend. The following diagram describes the complete flow. The main points are the following: Sibling services use Rainbow accounts that have to be created manually with the desired level of rights. Depending the services provided, REST API can be used instead of the SDK for NodeJS. Both cases work in the same way. For Rainbow third party applications As mentionned in the table above, authentication of these applications relies on the third party

excerpt: DocumentationRainbow usersRainbow users Preamble Rainbow users are in the center of the relationship machine. Understanding how Rainbow users are managed and work is important to build the best experi
content: DocumentationRainbow usersRainbow users Preamble Rainbow users are in the center of the relationship machine. Understanding how Rainbow users are managed and work is important to build the best experience in your application. This guide describes in details some main concepts that you need to know: What are the different roles of users in Rainbow and the associated rights ? How profiles impact the rights of a user ? How applications impact the rights of a user ? Why the user's company location is important ? Introduction on roles in Rainbow In Rainbow, different roles exist to offer individual experiences: Sometimes, you need to have users with a limited connection time while sometimes, you need to do administrative tasks such as creating new Rainbow accounts. These different behaviors can be obtained by giving to the user who executes the action a specific role. In Rainbow, there are three main different roles: The User role, the Guest role and the Administrator role. All these kind of users may interact each other and are not limited to dialog with users of the same role. User role The user role is the basic role used in Rainbow. By default when creating an account you have the user role. With this role, a user can interact with anybody by actions like sending an instant message, calling in audio or video, sharing his computer screen, a file, etc... The main characteristics are: Accounts with user role never expire (as opposed to accounts with guest role). Accounts with user role can connect to our ALE Rainbow applications and are not limited to third party applications (as opposed to accounts with guest role). Accounts with user role can't do administrative tasks (as opposed) to accounts with administrator role). Account of type user can be created by using the Node.JS SDK or directly from our REST APIs. Guest role (CPaaS role) The guest role can be seen as the user role but with a limited set of capabilities and a limited life duration. Concretely, this role has to be used when a user will have a short interaction with Rainbow such as when visiting a Web site and when this interaction could stay anonymous or with a limited identity (for example we don't need that the user logs in to his account). The main characteristics are: Accounts with guest role expire. By default after 48 hours but this duration can be fixed guest by guest at creation step. Once expired, Rainbow interactions are refused for this account. Accounts with guest role can't connect to our ALE Rainbow applications. These accounts have to be created and used exclusively in third party applications. Accounts with guest role can't have a network: No user can be added to the guest's network (subject to change). Accounts with guest role can’t be added to a user's network. Accounts with guest role can’t do search (subject to change). Accounts with guest role can't be found by search. Accounts with guest role can’t post a file (can receive files). Accounts with guest role can’t create a bubble, a channel or a group (can be added into bubbles, channels or groups). Accounts with guest role can't be associated to a PBX device. Account of type guest can be created by using the Node.JS SDK or directly from our REST APIs. 💡 NOTE Don't confuse CPaaS user Guest role with the UCaaS feature joining a Bubble in guest Mode. UCaaS guestMode is totally independent of CPaaS role. It was designed for joining a Bubble with meet.openrainbow.com for users without any account. Administrator role The administrator role don't exist practically but is in fact a set of different roles for doing administrative, provisionning or business tasks. The most common administrator role is the admin role. When having the admin role, an account can do administrative tasks and provisionning tasks. Two types (meaning levels) of admin roles exist: the company_admin type and the org_admin type. The role admin of type company_admin is given to any accounts who manage a company and the users included. When managing several companies, we use the role admin of type org_admin. For Business Partners, others roles exist for being able to buy & sell licenses such as bp_admin and bp_finance. For developers, they are administrators of their owned applications and so have the role of app_admin. The main characteristics are: Accounts with administrator role never expire. Accounts with administrator role have the user role too. An account can have several administrator roles such as admin and app_admin. Accounts with admin or app_admin role can't do business tasks (unlike accounts with bp_admin or bp_finance role). Accounts with admin or bp_admin/bp_finance can't manage applications (unlike accounts with app_admin role) Rights in Rainbow Rights given by roles As described in the previous paragraph, the role gives to the account a set of global rights that can be divided between Communication right, Administration right and Business right: Communication right is the right to send and receive ins

content: SDK Rainbow pour l'environnement AndroidConnectez votre application Android à RainbowTout ce dont vous avez besoin pour démarrer avec le SDK Rainbow pour Android.Prêt à commencer avec le SDK Rainbow pour Android?Tout ce dont vous avez besoin pour démarrer avec le SDK Rainbow pour Android.Premiers pas avec le SDK AndroidConsulter les exemples AndroidInformations pratiquesVersion: Publiée: Dernière mise à jour: 20 mars 2024Consulter le journal des modificationsBasculer vers la documentation STSUn SDK pour le développement d'applications AndroidNous fournissons un SDK Rainbow pour votre plate-forme Android de développement mobile. Ce SDK permet de connecter votre application mobile à Rainbow pour amener des appels vocaux et vidéo ainsi qu'un chat en "one-to-one" au sein d'une bulle avec plusieurs participants.SDK Rainbow pour AndroidPush NotificationsLe SDK Rainbow pour Android en un coup d'œil.Découvrez les principaux services fournis par ce SDKBibliothèque AndroidLe SDK pour Android est construit à l'aide des technologies natives les plus récentes fournies par cette plateforme afin de fournir une bibliothèque de grande efficacité pour votre application.Service de contacts, de recherche et de présenceGérez votre liste de contacts et sachez quand ils sont disponibles, occupés au téléphone ou absents et donc quand vous pouvez les joindre. Recherchez des utilisateurs par nom ou identifiant pour étendre votre réseau.Service de messagerie instantanée en tête-à-têteSoyez notifié des messages entrants des utilisateurs, acquittez-les et envoyez des réponses à vos destinataires. Vous pouvez récupérer l'intégralité de la conversation ou uniquement les messages les plus récents.Service de conversation de groupe (bulles)Créez et invitez des utilisateurs, ou reutilisez vos Bulles afin de discuter ensemble. Dans une Bulle, tout le monde peut participer à la conversation.Service WebRTC audio et vidéoVous pouvez lancer des appels audio et vidéo avec vos contacts en utilisant votre mobile en passant par WebRTC. Ajoutez la vidéo à l'audio. Basculez de la caméra avant vers la caméra arrière et contrôlez l'appel (activez/désactivez le son).Service de conférence WebRTCVous pouvez vous connecter aux conférences téléphoniques dans une bulle. Contrôlez la vidéo que vous souhaitez voir et contrôlez votre appareil (activez/désactivez le son).Service de partage de fichiersPartagez des fichiers avec un utilisateur dans le cadre d'une conversation Rainbow en "tête-à-tête" ou au sein d'une bulle Rainbow avec plusieurs participants. Téléchargez des fichiers partagés par d'autres dans l'espace de stockage cloud de Rainbow.Service de groupesRegroupez vos contacts par activité, autres,... . Faites de certains groupes vos groupes favoris.Service de chaînes d'informationEnvoyez des messages aux chaînes d'information qui peuvent être souscrites par des milliers d'utilisateurs. Abonnez-vous aux chaînes d'information publiques d'autres utilisateurs pour les suivre et recevoir ce qu'ils publient!Liens intéressantsApprendre à utiliser nos SDKsBesoin d'aide?Contactez notre équipe supportVisitez notre page d'accueilFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions légalesContrat de servicesContrat de développeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur

excerpt: DocumentationConnect to RainbowLTS release 2.61.0Publiée le 202-04-06Connect to Rainbow This tutorial details how you connect to Rainbow and more generally how you deal with the authentication and the
content: DocumentationConnect to RainbowLTS release 2.61.0Publiée le 202-04-06Connect to Rainbow This tutorial details how you connect to Rainbow and more generally how you deal with the authentication and the connection parts. These steps are mandatory in order to have access to services such as voice and video calls, chat or files sharing, etc... Rainbow conceptDescription Sandbox platform for developersThis Rainbow platform is dedicated to developers.The Sandbox platform for developers is not connected to the Production platform and let developers be familiar with our APIs and SDKs.This platform uses different users accounts and application Id. Some limitations can occur regarding the performance and availability. Production platformThis Rainbow platform is the official one with all Rainbow services and infrastructures enabling a high availability and accessibility all over the world.For using it, you need to create and deploy an application.This is the platform you use when connecting with our Rainbow applications. Preamble Incorporating the SDK facilitates connectivity with Rainbow through two distinct mechanisms: HTTP REST Requests: REST requests are used to interact with Rainbow services to perform actions such as creating a Room, inviting users, etc. They are executed through the various APIs available in the SDK modules. For most APIs, the user must be authenticated. Persistent Websocket Connection: The SDK establishes and maintains a persistent connection to Rainbow through a WebSocket, enabling real-time event reception. This connection enables instantaneous updates, including incoming chat messages, call notifications, and various dynamic events. The WebSocket remains active while the application is in the foreground but suspends when the application moves to the background. To continue receiving notifications when the application is in the background or closed, it's essential to subscribe to Push Notifications. This step ensures uninterrupted notification delivery. The SDK automatically manages the WebSocket connection post user authentication and provides monitoring capabilities via the RainbowSdk().connection().state property This tutorial assumes that you have followed the Getting Started tutorial and that you have an active Rainbow application. Sign-in to Rainbow kotlin java RainbowSdk().connection().signIn(email, password, object : Connection.ISignInListener { override fun onSignInFailed(errorCode: Connection.ErrorCode, error: RainbowError<Unit>) { val errorMessage = when (errorCode) { Connection.ErrorCode.CONNECTION_WRONG_LOGIN_OR_PWD -> "Incorrect username or password" else -> "An error occurred" } // Handle error cases } override fun onSignInSucceeded() { // User authentication successful } }) RainbowSdk.instance().connection().signIn(email, password, new Connection.ISignInListener() { @Override public void onSignInFailed(@NonNull Connection.ErrorCode errorCode, @NonNull RainbowError<Unit> error) { // Handle error cases } @Override public void onSignInSucceeded() { // User authentication successful } }); You can find all the connection error cases in the documentation for the ErrorCode class. During the authentication phase, the RainbowSdk().connection().state property will transition between these states: DISCONNECTED -> Before calling the sign-in method AUTHENTICATING -> During the call to the sign-in method AUTHENTICATED -> After successful authentication READY -> When the XMPP connection is established After authenticating the first time, the connection information is saved and can be retrieved in the RainbowSdk().user() module. kotlin java val storedLogin = RainbowSdk().user().userLoginInCache val storedPassword = RainbowSdk().user().userPasswordInCache String storedLogin = RainbowSdk.instance().user().getUserLoginInCache(); String storedPassword = RainbowSdk.instance().user().getUserPasswordInCache(); Sign-in on a different host The sign-in methods within the SDK module offer a version that enables specifying the authentication host. This functionality provides the flexibility to select between platforms, such as the sandbox or production, as needed. kotlin java RainbowSdk().connection().signIn(email, password, "sandbox.openrainbow.com", object : Connection.ISignInListener { override fun onSignInFailed(errorCode: Connection.ErrorCode, error: RainbowError<Unit>) { val errorMessage = when (errorCode) { Connection.ErrorCode.CONNECTION_WRONG_LOGIN_OR_PWD -> "Incorrect username or password" else -> "An error occurred" } // Handle error cases } override fun onSignInSucceeded() { // User authentication successful } }) RainbowSdk.instance().connection().signIn(email, password, "sandbox.openrainbow.com", new Connection.ISignInListener() { @Override public void onSignInFailed(@NonNull Connection.ErrorCode errorCode, @NonNull RainbowError<Unit> error) { // Handle error cases } @Override public void onSignInSucceeded() { // User authentication successful } }); Host Connection Rules When utilizing a si
