excerpt: DocumentationHello World (legacy)LTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Hello, World! Following the decades-long tradition, we are pleased to present the "Hello, World!" tutorial that will walk you thr
content:
DocumentationHello World (legacy)LTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Hello, World! Following the decades-long tradition, we are pleased to present the "Hello, World!" tutorial that will walk you through the basic steps required to launch your first application that uses Rainbow Web SDK. If you wonder how to set up the development environment and basic application structure, you are in the right place. If you have already built an app, this article will reiterate through the fundamental app structure in case you got lost on the way. At the end of this tutorial you will have a working application that could be considered as a starting point for developing an app using Rainbow Web SDK. You will also get the basic notion of the key Rainbow Web SDK concepts. The goal is to keep it simple, therefore we will be using the basic folder structure and vanilla JavaScript. This will be less disturbing for the new developers and expose the Rainbow Web SDK features to the veterans. Set up your development environment Before you start using Rainbow Web SDK, you need to make sure you have installed the required software tools. Install Node.js and NPM Make sure you have installed Node.js and NPM on your computer by running the following commands: $ node --version > v8.10.0 $ npm --version > 3.5.2 If any of those commands does not return a version number, follow the installation guides (Node, NPM) Browser We will be using Chrome or Firefox to develop, but you can use any of the browsers supported by Rainbow Web SDK. Text editor Rainbow Web SDK is a JavaScript library, therefore you can use any IDE to develop your first project. Create your web application As mentioned above, the project is going to use a basic structure of a simple JavaScript application. We will need a basic HTML structure that would load all the necessary libraries. Go on and create a new folder. We recommend using command line tools. Open a shell console and execute the following commands: $ mkdir myFirstRainbowProject $ cd myFirstRainbowProject $ npm init Answer the asked questions. Once finished, you should have your JSON file package.json filled with the information. This step is required to install the required NPM libraries. Install Rainbow Web SDK Now, it's time to install the Rainbow Web SDK library. Starting Rainbow 1.29, the SDK for Web is available as an NPM package to make the installation and updates easier. To install it, execute the following command (make sure you navigate to your project folder first): $ npm i -s rainbow-web-sdk Once Rainbow Web SDK has been installed, your project directory should look like this: . ├── node_modules │ └── rainbow-web-sdk │ ├── dist-legacy │ │ └── lib │ │ ├── loader-sdk.min.js │ │ ├── rainbow-sdk.min.js │ │ └── vendors-sdk.min.js │ ├── src │ │ ├── loader-sdk.min.js │ │ ├── rainbow-sdk.min.js │ │ └── vendors-sdk.min.js │ ├── LICENSE │ └── package.json └── package.json The Rainbow Web SDK has been added to your folder node_modules. This folder contains all the packages installed from NPM Installing a local Web server To test your application, you will need an HTTP Web server. You can install one (HTTP-Server) by executing the following command: $ npm i -D http-server Copying SDK files If you're building a Web application without using tools like Grunt, Gulp, Brunch or Webpack or without using JavaScript framework like React, you need to manually copy the Rainbow Web SDK files to your public directory. You can execute the following command: $ mkdir public $ cp ./node_modules/rainbow-web-sdk/dist-legacy/vendors-sdk.min.js public/ $ cp ./node_modules/rainbow-web-sdk/dist-legacy/rainbow-sdk.min.js public/ Create your first HTML file We have installed all the basic libraries necessary to create a simple project. We can now focus on creating a HTML skeleton file that would hold our app intact. Open a shell console and execute the following commands: $ cd public $ touch index.html Loading the Rainbow Web SDK library Open the file public/index.html with your text editor of choice and add the following lines to load the Rainbow Web SDK library: My First Rainbow Application

My First Rainbow Application

Rainbow Web SDK depends on some libraries that have to be loaded first like

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationInitiating audio and video callsLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Initiating Audio and Video calls Using Rainbow Web SDK, you can make audio and video calls towards your contacts than
content: DocumentationInitiating audio and video callsLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Initiating Audio and Video calls Using Rainbow Web SDK, you can make audio and video calls towards your contacts thanks to WebRTC. This tutorial will help you understanding how it works and will give you the hints for adding the possibility in your application to communicate in audio and video successfully. You can also start a WebRTC Conference (or desktop sharing) in a given Bubble (only one at a given time). If you want to see how to use Rainbow Web SDK to create a simple conferencing application, please have a look at our public GitHub Repository: Rainbow Web SDK - WebRTC Sample. Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understanding this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails A peerA peer is a participant of a call in a peer-to-peer call or in a conference call. A legA leg is a kind of media shared in a call. It can be: audio, video or sharing WebRTC Peer to Peer CallThis is a call between 2 users. One is the caller, the second is the callee or the recipient. WebRTC Conference callThis is a call between 2 or more users. An audio only CallAn audio only call uses only the microphone for dispatching the audio leg to the recipient. An audio and Video callAn audio and video call uses the microphone and a camera for dispatching both audio and video legs to the recipient. A sharing callA sharing call uses the screen or an application for dispatching a data leg to the recipient. The call can be initiated with or without an audio leg. The audio leg can be added during the call. Escalate to video callWhen in an audio call, you can decide at any time to add a video leg with your recipients. This mechanism is called an escalation (i.e. adding a new leg to an existing call). Be careful, this is not a mutual escalation. Each participant can decide to escalate or not on his own. Preamble Rainbow Web SDK allows to make audio video calls. To do so, the Web SDK relies on the WebRTC stack included in your compliant browser. The Web SDK supports one-to-one audio and video call and conference call. In order to be able to make an audio and video call between you and other recipients, you need: A compliant browser: At this time of writing only Firefox and Chrome browsers are supported by Rainbow Web SDK. Consequently, you have to use one of these browsers to make an audio and video call. HTTPS: In order to use Rainbow audio and video API, you need to serve your application using HTTPS. A negotiation server: A server for exchanging the audio and video negotiation part between all participants of the call. Rainbow will do it, you don't need to care about this part. A signaling protocol: To establish a call between two participants or several ones in a conference, a signaling protocol is used to allow each peer to negotiate all required parameters for exchanging correctly his audio and video legs with the others participants. Rainbow Web SDK integrates this protocol so that you have nothing to do on that part. Relay servers: Depending your network condition, a STUN server could be needed to allow your application to know how to be joined from Rainbow or from a recipient. An additional media relay server (TURN) could be needed for relaying the communication when there are blocking network elements (i.e. a firewall) between the users and between the users and Rainbow when in a conference. Rainbow has several TURN and STUN servers dispatched all around the world that will be used if needed. You don't need to care about this part. As you can see, the Web SDK provides you with all the complicated things you need: no signaling part to manage, no STUN or TURN server to deploy... Detecting your browser compatibility Rainbow Web SDK can help you checking if the browser can do WebRTC calls. Use the method canMakeAudioVideoCall() such as in the following code sample: /* Somewhere in your application... */ /* Call this method to know if your application can make audio and video call */ if(rainbowSDK.webRTC.canMakeAudioVideoCall()) { /* Your browser is compliant: You can make audio and video call using WebRTC in your application */ } else { /* Your browser is not compliant: Do not propose audio and video call in your application */ } This is the easier way to detect that your browser is compliant with WebRTC. But you can use your own code to do that by calling directly the WebRTC APIs. Once you know that your browser is compliant, you need to know if a webcam or at least a microphone is available in order to make audio or video call. Call the method hasACamera() and hasaMicrophone() to check the device detected by your browser. /* Somewhere in your application... */ /* Call this method to know if a webcam is detected */ if(rainbowSDK.webRTC.hasACamera()) { /* A webcam is available, you can make video call */ ... } else { /* No webcam detected */ ... } /* Call this method to know if a microphone is detected */ if(rainbowSDK.webRTC.hasAMicroph

excerpt: DocumentationIntegrating with FrameworksLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Integrating in JavaScript frameworks Even if the SDK for Web is an AngularJS 1.x based library, it can be used in any kind
content: DocumentationIntegrating with FrameworksLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Integrating in JavaScript frameworks Even if the SDK for Web is an AngularJS 1.x based library, it can be used in any kind of JavaScript applications that are either not based on this AngularJS 1.x version or based on libraries like Backbone, React, Ember, Vue, Bootstrap or jQuery. This tutorial helps you integrate the Rainbow SDK for Web in your own JavaScript environment. Preamble Integrating a JavaScript library into an existing Web application is not often an easy step and sometimes takes time. This tutorial is here to help you integrate our Rainbow SDK for Web library in your web site or web application to benefit from our Rainbow services. If you have never used our Rainbow SDK, the best way to start is to follow our Getting Started guide. Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understand this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails EventsEvents are asynchronous messages or notifications that come from Rainbow when something related to your data happens. By listening to theses events, your application will be able to react and inform the user of these changes. MethodsMethods are all the SDK functions your application can call to enable Rainbow services such as initiating a WebRTC call, sending a file, etc. In most of the cases, Methods are asynchronous and follow the JavaScript Promise pattern. Installation, loading and initializing Follow Hello World - ESM guide to find out how install, load and initialize Rainbow Web SDK. Calling SDK Methods Once your application has been loaded and initialized successfully, you can call Rainbow SDK methods by using the keyword rainbowSDK followed by a service name such as contacts or bubbles and a method name like getContactById(). rainbowSDK is a global variable accessible from everywhere in your application once you have bootstrapped the SDK. For example, you can initiate a WebRTC call by using the method rainbowSDK.webRTC.callInVideo(aContact). Most of the time methods are asynchronous and return a JavaScript Promise. Access to SDK Constants You can access Call and SDK constant directly from rainbowSDK object: let Call = rainbowSDK.Call; let SDK = rainbowSDK.SDK; Integrating the SDK for Web in React, Vue and Angular We have published several starter kits that can be downloaded from GitHub. You can use them to quickly start a new project using your framework of choice and the Rainbow SDK for Web. The source code of the starter kits can be downloaded from our GitHub. Do not hesitate to enhance them or to propose other integrations. excerpt: DocumentationInteracting with usersLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Interacting with users, bots and things Rainbow is called a relationship machine because by using our SDKs and APIs you can fin
content: DocumentationInteracting with usersLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Interacting with users, bots and things Rainbow is called a relationship machine because by using our SDKs and APIs you can find users, bots and things, keep a link with each of them, make groups and interact with them in a unique way. Additionally, you can create privileged relations with them that let you access to information such as their availability. Doing so let you build a lot of scenarios and could help you knowing the best way to reach them. The Rainbow SDK for Web offers a lot of methods that will be covered in that guide to let you build and manage your relationships. Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understanding this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails A contactA contact is a Rainbow user who is in the network of the connected user. The networkThis is the list of contacts with whom you are sharing mutually your availability such as your phone presence, you activity presence, etc... Network is empty by default and can grow by sending and accepting invitations to Rainbow users. This action is call joining the network. An invitationAn invitation to join the network is a request that can be sent to any Rainbow users who can be found by the search engine. An invitation can be accepted or declined.When accepted, the user is added to the network or other user and inversely. When declined, the request is discarded. A groupUsers in Rainbow can be gathered by defining groups. Groups allow to categorize and organize your relations, friends, colleagues, bots, connected things, etc. Preamble As indicated in the introduction, using Rainbow, you can interact with users, bots or things. Having an interaction means: Being able to discover any entities such a users, bots or things Being able to dialog actively with them for example by making a video call with an user or receiving an instant message from a bot Being able to keep a link to them (e.g. retrieving the conversation or creating groups) And being able to get passive information from them such as their connection presence, phone presence, etc.- which means having a privileged relation. The different kinds of interactions are described in the following paragraphs. Discovering Rainbow entities The first thing to do to interact with users is to be able to find them. This step can be done with the integrated search engine. The SDK for Web has several methods to let you search or get Rainbow users. Searching by name If you know the firstname or the lastname or just some part of those data, you can use the method searchByName(). Using it, you need to specify at least the beginning of the name or the first name. Try to give as much information as you have in order to avoid having too many results. Here is an example of using this method: rainbowSDK.contacts.searchByName("Jon Doe", 10).then(function(usersFound) { if(usersFound.length > 0) { // At least one user has been found usersFound.forEach(function(user) { // Do something with each contact returned }); } else { // No contact returned } If you do not specify any values for the limit parameter, a maximum of 20 results will be returned. No more 1000 results can be returned. This is the common method when searching for a user or a bot. Searching by Id or by Jid If you know either the Rainbow id of the user or his jid, you can use the method searchById() or searchByJid() instead. These methods return the user if found or null elsewhere. rainbowSDK.contacts.searchById("5be9826de3bc5e54c13e00bd").then(function(entityFound) { if(entityFound.) { // Do something with the entity found } else { // No entity returned } There are the common methods when searching for a bot or a connected thing. Interacting with users and things As mentioned previously, users or things are represented by the same structure that is a Contact. Once you have a Contact object representing a Rainbow user, a bot or a connected thing, you can use several methods to interact with. For example: For exchanging instant messages and files: Use the method openConversationForContact() from Conversations service. Once conversation is created or retrieved, you can send messages and files. For calling him in video: To initiate an audio or audio and video call, use the method callInAudio() or callInVideo() from the WebRTC service. For collaborating with him in Bubbles: Use the method inviteContactToBubble() from the Bubbles service to invite him to your bubble. For sending him notifications: Use the method addMembersToChannel() from the Channels service to add him to a channel. For calling him by phone: Use the method callByNumber() from the Telephony service to call him on his phone device. For keeping a direct link: Use the method addContactInGroup() from the Groups service to add him to one of your groups. See the next paragraph for more details on Groups. For sharing your presence Send an invitation to your network by calling the method addToNetwork()

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationWeb > lts > guides > Loading_Angular_1x_applicationsLoading AngularJS 1.x applications In this tutorial, you will discover how to setup the config.json file right for loading the SDK for
content: DocumentationWeb > lts > guides > Loading_Angular_1x_applicationsLoading AngularJS 1.x applications In this tutorial, you will discover how to setup the config.json file right for loading the SDK for Web, its dependencies and your application files. This way of loading is designed to be used in AngularJS 1.x based applications only. If your application is based on an other JavaScript front-end framework like Backbone, React, Ember, jQuery or recent version of Angular, please have a look at the guide Getting Started; this tutorial will help you loading and using the SDK for Web in your specific environment. Preamble In order to propose an easy way for loading and configuring your application, we decided to remove the complexity from the index.html file by keeping only the minimum viable tags. All the others things (i.e. the list of files to load, the settings) will be loaded from a configuration file. Like explained in the previous tutorial, the first thing you have to do is to add the following lines to your HTML file: <!-- Add the following lines to your 'index.html' file --> <html lang="en" ng-controller="sampleController"> <body> ... <script src="/path_to_loader/loader-sdk.min.js" data-main="./config.json"></script> ... </body> </html> By default the file config.json will be used as your configuration file. You can rename it or load it from an other place. Do not forget to update the path! Note: As you can see, the 'ng-app' attribute that lets you bootstrap your application is no more needed (it will be defined inside the configuration file). Understanding the loading steps This configuration file is divided into several parts that are loaded one after the other in order to keep some logical order and avoid for example to load the applications file that depend on the SDK before it. There are 5 steps for loading your application: Step 1: Load the pre-requisites libraries: The first step is to load the libraries needed by the SDK. In most of the cases, you do not have to modify these parts except if you want to remove ones that you have already been loaded by your own Step 2: Load the SDK for Web: Once the prerequisites are loaded, the SDK for Web follows Step 3: Load the others libraries: There part can be empty or contains additional libraries that need to be loaded after the SDK for Web Step 4: Load the applications files: Once all of the "framework" part has been loaded, the applications files are loaded too Step 5: Bootstrap the application: Once all is loaded, the application is bootstrapped and then ready to start which means that your main controller is called (in case of an AngularJS application). The following paragraphs will focus on each of the steps above to help you understand and setup the configuration file. Discovering the configuration file Here is the content of the configuration file you need to have in order to load all your files correctly. You can copy and paste this config.json sample and adapt it to fit your needs. { "libraries": { "prerequisites": [ "//code.jquery.com/jquery-2.1.3.min.js", "//cdn.jsdelivr.net/momentjs/2.15.1/moment-with-locales.min.js", "//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.5.7/angular.min.js" // for Rainbow Web SDK versions > 1.53 use : "//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.7.5/angular.min.js" ], "sdk": { "official": [ "path_to_vendors_file/vendors-sdk.min.js", "path_to_rainbow_file/rainbow-sdk.min.js" ], "default": "official" }, "after": [] }, "app": { "bootstrap": "sample", "key": { "appID": "", "appSecret": "" }, "js": ["./src/js/sdkSampleApp.js", "./src/js/components/connection/connectionCmp.js", "..."], "css": ["src/styles/sdkSampleApp.css", "src/js/components/connection/connectionCmp.css", "..."] }, "settings": { "verboseLog": true, "disableCache": true, "enableLoader": true } } Be careful when modifying the configuration file, it should be a valid JSON file (i.e. no comments). When you are modifying this file, you can open your browser developer console in order to see if all is correct (a lot of logs have been added to help you understand what is going on when something goes wrong). Loading the prerequisites The SDK for Web prerequisites are loaded first. As mentioned before, in most of the cases, you do not have to modify this part because if these files are not loaded first, the SDK for Web will not load and work correctly. { "libraries": { "prerequisites": [ "//code.jquery.com/jquery-2.1.3.min.js", "//cdn.jsdelivr.net/momentjs/2.15.1/moment-with-locales.min.js", "//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.5.7/angular.min.js" // for Rainbow Web SDK versions > 1.53 use : "//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.7.5/angular.min.js" ], ... } ... } By default these files are loaded from a CDN. You can change the path if you want to load them from a local directory. If your application depends on an other third-party libraries, you can add them in this part. They will be loaded for you. Note: The use of "//" lets the browser load t

excerpt: DocumentationManaging ChannelsLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Managing Channels Rainbow chat messages and audio and video calls are really effective when it comes to communication in relatively
content: DocumentationManaging ChannelsLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Managing Channels Rainbow chat messages and audio and video calls are really effective when it comes to communication in relatively small group. Once you want to reach an audience of, say, thousands, the information sent in a form of a chat can be not visible enough. Rainbow Web SDK comes with a solution to this problem: you can send notifications to a large numbers (e.i. several thousands) of users using a Channel. Channel can be used when you want to notify a large group of users without having to send a chat message individually to each of them. Think of it as a global notification system. You can create and administrate two different types of Channels: either by adding and managing the recipients yourself (closed Channels) or by letting all the users subscribe to the Channel (called public Channels) if they find receiving this information interesting. Channel typeDescription ClosedOnly Owner can add or remove users in a private channels. Private channels can't be found when searching for channels. Consequently, users can't subscribe on their own to private channel. PublicUsers are free to subscribe to a public channel. Public channels can be found when searching for channels. The visibility of a channel is limited to my company. In a channel, the membership of a user (role) can be owner, member, publisher or none. User roleDescription OwnerThe owner is the user who creates the channel. An owner can modify information of the channel, can invite other users (including new owners) can publish messages and can receive incoming messages PublisherA publisher is a member of a channel who can publish messages in that channel and can receive incoming messages MemberA member of a channel can only receive incoming messages NoneA user with this particular role is a user who left the channel (by his own or got removed by a owner) Getting started The basic interaction with Rainbow Channels is based on CRUD principles (create, read, update, delete). You can create, modify, retrieve and delete the Channels from Rainbow servers. Let's begin with creating one Channel. Creating Channel As mentioned above, you can create two types of Channel. Let us start with the Public Channel. To create a public Channel, you need to use createPublicChannel() method that accepts the following arguments: channelName (string), channelTopic (string), max_items (integer) and category (string) and returns a Promise. The example below shows one way of using the method: // somewhere in your code rainbowSDK.channels.createPublicChannel("My First Public Channel", "Topic of the channel", 20, "Technology") .then(channel => console.log("Created a new Channel!", channel)) .catch(err => console.log(err)); If everything went fine, a new public Channel should be created. Analogically, we can create a closed Channel by using createClosedChannel() method: // somewhere in your code rainbowSDK.channels.createClosedChannel("My First Closed Channel", "Topic of the channel", 20, "Technology") .then(channel => console.log("Created a new Channel!", channel) /*do something with the Channel object*/) .catch(err => console.log(err) /*something went wrong*/); Fetching the Channels Once the Channels have been created, we can try to verify whether they are saved in the database by using fetchMyChannels() method that retrieves Channels from the server. This method returns a Promise. //somewhere in your code rainbowSDK.channels.fetchMyChannels() .then(channels => /*do something with the Channels array */) .catch(err => console.log(err) /*something went wrong*/); Other method of fetching a Channel is offered by fetchChannel() method that accepts id string as a parameter: rainbowSDK.channels.fetchChannel("channel ID") .then(channel => /*do something with the channel retrieved from the server */) .catch(err => console.log(err) /*something went wrong*/); There are few more methods that allow you to fetch a Channel by name, topic or description, however they will look through the public Channels only. rainbowSDK.channels.fetchChannelsByName("channel name") .then(channel => /*do something with the channel retrieved from the server */) .catch(err => console.log(err) /*something went wrong*/); rainbowSDK.channels.fetchChannelsByTopic("channel topic") .then(channel => /*do something with the channel retrieved from the server */) .catch(err => console.log(err) /*something went wrong*/); rainbowSDK.channels.fetchChannelsByCategory("channel category") .then(channel => /*do something with the channel retrieved from the server */) .catch(err => console.log(err) /*something went wrong*/); Updating the Channels Rainbow Web SDK comes with a set of that allow you to update most of the Channel's properties: updateChannelName(), updateChannelTopic(), updateChannelCategory(), updateChannelAvatar(), updateChannelVisibilityToPublic(), updateChannelVisibilityToClosed(). The snippets below will demonstrate the way you can use t

excerpt: DocumentationManaging FavoritesLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Managing Favorites Rainbow Web SDK allows you to store links to conversations with Users and Bubbles in a handy list called Favorit
content: DocumentationManaging FavoritesLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Managing Favorites Rainbow Web SDK allows you to store links to conversations with Users and Bubbles in a handy list called Favorites. Favorites are essentially a JavaScript array containing objects. Each of those objects the following properties: type - describing a type of a Favorite. Can be set either to user or bubble id - representing an ID of a Favorite peerId - a dbId property of a Bubble or User that is linked to Favorite object contact or room - essentially a contact or bubble object that is linked to Favorite item With those four you will have a good peak on what Users or Bubbles are the most used and essential for the application. Retrieving Favorites List You can retrieve Favorites List from the server by calling fetchAllFavorites() method that returns an Array. Favorites Array can be empty when no User or Bubble has been added to Favorites. It is an asynchronous method, therefore it returns a Promise containing the Favorites Array. // somewhere in your code rainbowSDK.favorites.fetchAllFavorites() .then(function (favorites) { // do something with the Favorites Array retrieved from the server }) .catch(function (err) { console.log (err) }) Creating a Favorite To create a Favorite (add a new object to the Favorites list), use the favorites.createFavorite() method which accepts a Bubble or User dbId and type as arguments. createFavorite() returns a Promise due to its asynchronous nature. A snippet below shows how to create a Favorite of each of the types: var user = UserObject; var bubble = BubbleObject; // Create a new Favorite from an User: rainbowSDK.favorites.createFavorite(user.dbId, "user") .then( // do something once the Favorite has been created ) .catch( // do something in case of an error ) // Create a new Favorite from a Bubble: rainbowSDK.favorites.createFavorite(bubble.dbId, "bubble") .then( // do something once the Favorite has been created ) .catch( // do something in case of an error ) Once a new Favorite is created, an event is going to be sent. Think of it as a confirmation of the successful Favorite creation process. // somewhere in your code: favoriteCreatedEventListener(event) { // event.detail contains an object of the freshly-created Favorite console.log("Favorite created", event.detail) } document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.favorites.RAINBOW_ONFAVORITECREATED, favoriteCreatedEventListener) Deleting a Favorite Analogically, it is possible to delete a Favorite from the Favorites list by calling the favorites.deleteFavorite() method which accepts a Favorite ID string. It is asynchronous and it returns a Promise. var favorite = FavoriteObject; // Favorite Object // Delete a Favorite rainbowSDK.favorites.deleteFavorite(favorite.id) .then(// do something once the Favorite has been deleted) .catch(// do something in case of an error) Similarly to creating a Favorite, while deleting one, an event will be dispatched. It is a definite confirmation that a Favorite has been deleted. favoriteDeletedEventListener(event) { // event.detail contains an object of the freshly-created Favorite console.log("Favorite deleted", event.detail) } document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.favorites.RAINBOW_ONFAVORITEDELETED, favoriteDeletedEventListener) Last updated April, 30th 2019 Sur cette pageManaging FavoritesRetrieving Favorites ListCreating a FavoriteDeleting a FavoriteCe contenu vous a-t-il été utile ?OuiNonFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions légalesContrat de servicesContrat de développeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationOAuth2 authenticationLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21OAuth Authentication This tutorial shows how you can use OAuth 2.0 authentication method in your application. Rainbow uses OAuth
content: DocumentationOAuth2 authenticationLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21OAuth Authentication This tutorial shows how you can use OAuth 2.0 authentication method in your application. Rainbow uses OAuth 2.0 protocol to ensure authentication and authorization. One of the advantages of using OAuth 2.0 protocol is removing the responsibility for storing the user credentials from the third-party applications developers. Also, by outsourcing the authentication flow to Rainbow servers, the developers no longer need to maintain their own servers and ensure the application of numerous security measures. It also provides a set of advantages for the users who want to restrict the usage of their personal data linked to a Rainbow account. With OAuth 2.0 the users can also limit or even revoke the access of the third-party applications to their data. The main principle of OAuth 2.0 protocol is to separate the role of the client from that of the resource owner (Rainbow). Basic Concepts The basic idea behind the OAuth 2.0 is to ensure a protocol flow between the three (optionally four) principal roles explained in the context of Rainbow flow below: Resource owner - user providing an access to his data (protected resource) Resource server - Rainbow server hosting the protected resources Client - Third-party application trying to access resources on behalf of the Resource Owner Authorization server - Server which sends the authorization token to the Resource server Currently Rainbow Web SDK supports the so called Implicit flow which facilitates the authentication process for Single Page Applications written in JavaScript (or one of its frameworks). It excludes the necessity of involving an Authorization Server in the process. However, this approach has some limitations: the token is valid for only one hour. After that time it is required for user to run the sign in procedure again. Access token Access token is a string issued by Resource server (Rainbow server) to the Client (third-party application). It represents the authorization to access Resources. The end goal of the quite complicated OAuth 2.0 protocol process is to issue the token to the client and ensure secure access to the user data. Token replaces username and password by providing and abstraction layer. Therefore, once obtained, Access Token relieve the third-party applications from a duty of securing and keeping user data. Access token is a simplification of the idea of authentication, as it is represented by a single string understood by the Resource server. Requirements In order to use the benefits of OAuth 2.0 protocol in your application using Rainbow Web SDK, you need to follow the process of creating an application in our Rainbow for Developers. You will need two basic pieces of information: Application ID - ID of the application generated by Rainbow for Developers. Redirect URI - a URI of your choice that the user will be redirected to after giving a consent for your application to use his protected resources You can set Redirect URI either via Rainbow for Developers or Rainbow CLI. It is extremely important for the functioning of your application as our server will verify it each time a user will try to connect to Rainbow through your application. It is also the first and foremost layer of security granted by the Implicit flow. To set a redirect_uri attribute and assign it to your application, use rainbow-cli tool: rbw application set-redirecturi YOURAPPID YOURREDIRECTURI For more information on the application lifecycle, you can read the tutorial Application lifecycle. Implicit flow OAuth's implicit flow assumes that the Resource server can provide the protected resource based only on the Application ID. In order to use the implicit flow, you need to fully agree to all the security levels it proposes (see the part about security). To do so, go to rainbow-cli tool and run the following command in your shell: rbw application set-implicitgrant YOURAPPID You can revoke your application's authorization to use implicit flow by running the following command: rbw application unset-implicitgrant YOURAPPID To obtain the Authentication Token via the Implicit Flow, follow the steps below: Direct user to Rainbow authorization URL Your first action is to redirect a user to the Rainbow authorization page. In order to do so, you will need to build the redirect link that will consist of few mandatory parts: Rainbow Host URL - this parameter will always stay the same: https://RAINBOW_SERVER/api/rainbow/authentication/v1.0/oauth/authorize? Response type - parameter defining the type of response. As above, this part will stay the same in all of your requests: response_type=token Application ID - this is the part when you need to provide your application ID in the following format: &client_id=YOURAPPLICATIONID Redirect URI - another parameter that will define and protect your application (see previous step): &redirect_uri=https://YOURREDIRECTURI State - a random string gene

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationWeb > lts > guides > Retrieving_calls_historyRetrieving calls history In this tutorial, you will discover how to retrieve your call history. Each time you call a Rainbow user using audio
content: DocumentationWeb > lts > guides > Retrieving_calls_historyRetrieving calls history In this tutorial, you will discover how to retrieve your call history. Each time you call a Rainbow user using audio or video from your mobile application, your browser or when you call someone using your phone connected to a PBX, a call log entry is generated and added to your call history. This tutorial will help you understand how to deal with these information and manage your call history. Preamble The call history is not limited to audio and video calls done from Rainbow. Each time someone calls you on your phone associated to your Rainbow user or when you call someone with your phone device registered on Rainbow, a call log entry is generated and saved on Rainbow. The call history of the connected user will contain all these call log items. Each entry will contain the following structure: { contact: "318d07bcb19f449ba427b4672722b367@openrainbow.com", // User JID or phone number contactDisplayName: "Jon Smith", contactInitials: "JS", date: Thu Dec 07 2017 14:15:56 GMT+0100 (CET), direction: "incoming", // Or `outgoing` duration: "30m 45s", // 0 for missed call id: "web_83b73bc4-c22d-44ac-9c49-b83558231549", read: true, // false if new (not marked as read) state: "answered", // Or `missed` type: "webrtc" // or `telephone` } Here are some information regarding the parameters in that structure: Regarding the property contact, if the recipient is a Rainbow user, this property will contain the JID information. So using this information you are able to find the associated Rainbow contact information. If the recipient is not a Rainbow user, you can have only a phone number. Regarding the property read. Its value equals to false if it is a new entry that has not been marked as read. Regarding the property state. Its value equals to answered if the call has been established or would be set to missed otherwise. Regarding the property type. Its value equals to webrtc if the call has been done with the computer or the mobile using the WebRTC technology or telephone otherwise (for a PSTN call). Regarding the property direction. Its value equals to incoming when this is a call from a recipient to the connected user or outgoing when the call has been established by the connected user. Retrieving the call history Once the SDK for Web has started, you can retrieve the log history of the connected user by using the API getAll. This operation is not synchronous so to be sure that all the history has been received, you need to listen to the event RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGUPDATED. Here is an example for retrieving the call history when started: var onCallLogUpdated = function onCallLogUpdated() { var logHistory = rainbowSDK.callsLog.getAll(); // Do something with the log history }; document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.callsLog.RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGUPDATED, onCallLogUpdated) The API isInitialized() can be used to check if the initial log history has been retrieved from Rainbow. A true value returned means that the whole call log has been retrieved from Rainbow. Listening to new call history entry The same listener on RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGUPDATED can be used to listen to new call log entry. This new entry will be automatically added to the history. Calling the API Managing call history counter Generally speaking, when a call is missed a new call log entry is added to the history with the property read equals to false. So, when you need to know how many calls you missed, you can use the API getMissedCallLogCounter() such as in the following: var missedCallCounter = rainbowSDK.callsLog.getMissedCallLogCounter(); The variable missedCallCounter will be a number that represents the number of missed calls. And then, using the API getAll(), you will be able to retrieve these calls. In order to decrease this counter, you will have to mark these logs 'as read' (described in the next paragraph). Mark a call history entry as read To mark as read an existing missed call entry, you need to call the API markCallLogAsRead(). var onCallLogAckUpdated = function onCallLogAckUpdated() { //Do something when an acknowledgement has been done on the call history ... } var entry = rainbowSDK.callsLog.getAll()[0]; rainbowSDK.callsLog.markCallLogAsRead(entry.id); document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.callsLog.RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGACKUPDATED, onCallLogAckUpdated) Once this has been done, a new event RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGACKUPDATED is fired to inform that at least an acknowledgement has been done on the call history. Calling the API getAll() will give you an update of the call history and the property read of the associated entry has changed to true. By calling the API getMissedCallLogCounter(), you should have a smaller result. Note: The API markAllCallsLogsAsRead() mark all missed call to read in one step. Deleting call history items You can delete a call history item at any time by calling the API deleteOneCallLog() var entry = rainbowSDK.callsLog.getAll()[0]; rainbowSDK.callsLog.deleteOneCal

content: DocumentationSupported BrowsersLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Supported Browsers Rainbow Web SDK is supported on all the major browser engines: Google Chrome and Chromium-based browsers like Opera, Brave, Edge (version 56 and higher) Firefox (version 58 and higher) Edge (non-chromium, version 15 and higher) It is strongly recommended to update the browser version to the latest official release. Rainbow team provides support for most of the SDK features. It is best, though, to update to the latest Firefox and Chromium-based browser versions in order to ensure full WebRTC support. title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationUsing ConfigLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Using Config Rainbow Web SDK configuration allows the developers to provide a more fine-grained experience to their users. It is also ena
content: DocumentationUsing ConfigLTS release 4.0.0Publiée le 2022-12-21Using Config Rainbow Web SDK configuration allows the developers to provide a more fine-grained experience to their users. It is also enabling the customization of the project that uses the SDK. This article covers two basic ways of Rainbow Web SDK configuration Method 1: Config File While loading the SDK, you can pass a JavaScript object as an argument. Here's a quick snippet demonstrating the usage of the config object: const rainbowConfig = { verboseLog: false, // Turn on/off all the logs linked to the SDK measurePerformance: false, // Add performance measurement points while loading the SDK videoQuality: "1080p", // Chose default broadcasted video quality credentials: { appID: "", appSecret: "", host: "openrainbow.com" }, // use the credentials logs: { // use fine-grained logs control (verboseLog needs to be true) contactService: true, // set to false to block all contactService logs xmppMessages: true, // set to false to block all XMPP messages xmppService: true, // set to false to block xmppService logs conversationService: true, // set to false to block conversationService logs presence: true, // set to false to block presence logs } } rainbowSDK.load(rainbowConfig); The presented structure of rainbowConfig object above is loaded by the SDK by default. If you want to keep all the properties as they are, but change one - for instance verboseLog - you can just mention only verboseLog in the config object: const rainbowConfig = { verboseLog: true } rainbowSDK.load(rainbowConfig); Method 2: Config Service You can also use ConfigService provided by Rainbow Web SDK, please have a look at the documentation of the service to find out what APIs are available with more details on the implementation. Last updated March, 8th 2021 Sur cette pageUsing ConfigMethod 1: Config FileMethod 2: Config ServiceCe contenu vous a-t-il été utile ?OuiNonFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions légalesContrat de servicesContrat de développeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: SDK Rainbow pour le Web (2ème Edition)Le choix parfait pour votre site Web ou votre application WebPrêt à commencer avec le SDK Rainbow pour le Web ?Tout ce dont vous avez besoin pour démarrer avec le
content: SDK Rainbow pour le Web (2ème Edition)Le choix parfait pour votre site Web ou votre application WebPrêt à commencer avec le SDK Rainbow pour le Web ?Tout ce dont vous avez besoin pour démarrer avec le SDK Rainbow pour le Web.Premiers pas avec le SDK Webv2Télécharger le SDK Webv2Informations pratiquesVersion: LTS 5.0.0Publiée: 22 juin 2024Dernière mise à jour: 21 juin 2024Consulter le journal des modificationsBasculer vers la documentation STSIntégration facile à votre site WebLe SDK Rainbow pour le Web s'intègre facilement dans n'importe quel site Web ou application Web en ajoutant simplement quelques lignes de code. Une fois cela fait, votre site Web ou votre application sera connecté à Rainbow et capable d'utiliser tous les services Rainbow disponibles.Pour n'importe quel navigateurPour tout appareil ou système d'exploitationPour tout framework JSOffre une console de débogage convivialeUn SDK Web entièrement documentéLe SDK Rainbow pour le Web vous fournit les meilleurs services pour vous connecter à Rainbow et s'intégrer à votre site. Ces services ont été soigneusement développés et sont bien documentés avec les détails nécessaires pour vous aider à créer votre application.Des fonctionnalités de collaborations complètesLe SDK Rainbow pour le Web fournit les services dont vous avez besoin pour créer un réseau social complet. Faites de votre site une machine à relations. Discutez ou partagez des fichiers avec un seul destinataire ou avec un groupe. Passez un appel audio avec quelqu'un, ajoutez la vidéo. C'est très simple avec Rainbow !SDK Rainbow pour le Web en un coup d'œil.Découvrez les principaux services fournis par ce SDKSimple bibliothèque JSChargez le fichier JavaScript du SDK Rainbow à partir de votre site Web ou de votre application et utilisez-le avec quelques lignes de code. Il est compatible avec les principaux frameworks JavaScript tels que React, Angular et JQuery.Service de contacts, de recherche et de présenceGérez votre liste de contacts et sachez quand ils sont disponibles, occupés au téléphone ou absents et donc quand vous pouvez les joindre. Recherchez des utilisateurs par nom ou identifiant pour étendre votre réseau.Service de messagerie instantanée en tête-à-têteSoyez notifié des messages entrants des utilisateurs, acquittez-les et envoyez des réponses à vos destinataires. Vous pouvez récupérer l'intégralité de la conversation ou uniquement les messages les plus récents.Service de conversation de groupe (bulles)Créez et invitez des utilisateurs, ou reutilisez vos Bulles afin de discuter ensemble. Dans une Bulle, tout le monde peut participer à la conversation.Service WebRTC audio et vidéoVous pouvez lancer des appels audio et vidéo vers vos contacts en utilisant votre navigateur sans plug-in. Ajoutez la vidéo à un appel audio. Choisissez l'appareil que vous souhaitez utiliser et contrôlez l'appel (activez/désactivez le son).Service de conférence WebRTCVous pouvez vous connecter aux conférences téléphoniques dans une bulle. Contrôlez la vidéo que vous souhaitez voir et contrôlez votre appareil (activez/désactivez le son).Service de chaînes d'informationEnvoyez des messages aux chaînes d'information qui peuvent être souscrites par des milliers d'utilisateurs. Abonnez-vous aux chaînes d'information publiques d'autres utilisateurs pour les suivre et recevoir ce qu'ils publient!Liens intéressantsApprendre à utiliser nos SDKsBesoin d'aide?Contactez notre équipe supportVisitez notre page d'accueilFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions légalesContrat de servicesContrat de développeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur

Param the bubble related Param the user status ON_NEW_BUBBLE_CREATED ON_NEW_BUBBLE_CREATED: "ON_NEW_BUBBLE_CREATED" This RBEvent is send when there's a new bubble is created Param the new bubble related Param if TRUE, that means that the new bubble is created but some/all of the invited users are not successfully added; Only for bubbles/rooms created by the user Param The DbId of the contacts that could not be invited to the bubble ON_SERVICE_STARTED ON_SERVICE_STARTED: "ON_SERVICE_STARTED" This RBEvent is send when the bubble service is started and ready to be used (also fired after loss of network and reconnection) ON_USER_STATUS_UPDATE ON_USER_STATUS_UPDATE: "ON_USER_STATUS_UPDATE" This RBEvent is send when a there's an update on the bubbles participants status (invited, accepted, etc) Param the bubble related Param the user inside the bubble related Param the user status Sur cette pageEventsON_INVITATION_RECEIVEDParamON_MY_USER_PRIVILEGE_UPDATEParamParamParamON_MY_USER_STATUS_UPDATEParamParamON_NEW_BUBBLE_CREATEDParamParamParamON_SERVICE_STARTEDON_USER_STATUS_UPDATEParamParamParamCe contenu vous a-t-il été utile ?OuiNonFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions légalesContrat de servicesContrat de développeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur

content: DocumentationBubbleLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / Bubble Interface: Bubble Properties autoAcceptInvitation readonly autoAcceptInvitation: boolean When set to true, allows to automatically add participants in the bubble (default behavior is that participants need to accept the bubble invitation first before being a member of this bubble) avatar readonly avatar: string The bubble avatar avatarContacts readonly avatarContacts: any[] The avatar of each participants of the bubble containerId readonly containerId: string ID of container this bubble belongs to creationDate? optional readonly creationDate: Date The creation date of the bubble customData readonly customData: any Custom data associated to the bubble dbId readonly dbId: string The bubble database Identifier guestPhoneNumbers readonly guestPhoneNumbers: string[] List of guest phonenumbers history readonly history: string Allow newcomers to access or not messages history. If the value is "all", a newcomer can retrieve the full bubble messages history isActive readonly isActive: boolean True if the bubble is actived isAlertNotificationEnabled isAlertNotificationEnabled: boolean If the bubble has alert notification feature enabled isModerator readonly isModerator: boolean True if the bubble is moderated by the connected user isOwnedByGroup isOwnedByGroup: boolean If the bubble is created as part of Rainbow Voice Hunting group jid readonly jid: string The jid associated to this bubble lastActivityDate? optional readonly lastActivityDate: Date last activity date of bubble members readonly members: BubbleUser[] The members of the bubble name readonly name: string The name of the bubble nameForLogs readonly nameForLogs: string The name used in logs of the bubble organizers readonly organizers: BubbleUser[] The organizers of the bubble owner readonly owner: boolean True if the bubble is owned by the connected user ownerContact readonly ownerContact: any The owner of the bubble rxSubject readonly rxSubject: Subject<any> Observable subject for bubble status readonly status: BubbleUserStatus The status of the connected user in the bubble ('invited', 'accepted', 'unsubscribed', 'rejected' or 'deleted') tags readonly tags: any[] Tags describing the bubble topic readonly topic: string The topic of the bubble type readonly type: string The type of the bubble users readonly users: BubbleUser[] The list of users of the bubble (invited, joined and removed) usersReady readonly usersReady: BehaviorSubject<boolean> True when all bubble users have been retreived Methods acceptInvitation() acceptInvitation(): Promise<Bubble> Accept invitation to join a bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> addRainbowTVs() addRainbowTVs(androidTVs): Promise<Bubble> Add rainbow TVs to the bubble; Parameters • androidTVs: User[] users from type Rainbow TV Returns Promise<Bubble> addUser() addUser(user, privilege?, reason?, withoutInvitation?): Promise<Bubble> Add user to the bubble; Can be used to directly add user without invitation or as a moderator Parameters • user: User The user to add in the bubble • privilege?: BubbleUserPrivilege The user privilege in this bubble ('user', 'moderator' or 'guest'), by default is 'user' • reason?: string Text that will be join in the invitation • withoutInvitation?: boolean When set to true no invitation is sent Returns Promise<Bubble> changeOwner() changeOwner(newOwner): Promise<Bubble> Change the owner of the bubble Parameters • newOwner: User The user that should be the new owner Returns Promise<Bubble> createBubbleLink() createBubbleLink(): Promise<string> Method to create bubble "guest" access code Returns Promise<string> declineInvitation() declineInvitation(): Promise<Bubble> Decline invitation to join a bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> delete() delete(createArchive?): Promise<Bubble> Delete own bubble. If createArchive is TRUE, the bubble will be archived, i.e. all users can only read the content that's already in the bubble, but no further action can be done inside the bubble All participants in the bubble will go to UNSUBSCRIBED state (read-only) Parameters • createArchive?: boolean If TRUE, the bubble will be archived for all users (i.e. read only mode for all users still inside); Returns Promise<Bubble> deleteBubbleLink() deleteBubbleLink(): Promise<void> Method to delete bubble "guest" access code Returns Promise<void> getAllAcceptedUsers() getAllAcceptedUsers(): BubbleUser[] Method to retrieve all users of the bubble that have accepted Returns BubbleUser[] getAutoAcceptInvitation() getAutoAcceptInvitation(): boolean Method to retrieve autoAcceptInvitation status Returns boolean getAutoRegister() getAutoRegister(): string Method to retrieve auto register status Returns string getBubbleLink() getBubbleLink(): Promise<string> Method to get bubble "guest" access code Returns Promise<string> getDialInCode() getDialInCode(): string Method to retrieve conference.dialInCode code Returns string getDisableTimeSt

content: DocumentationBubbleServiceLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / BubbleService Interface: BubbleService The BubbleService interface defines the Rainbow SDK BubbleService API Methods createBubble() createBubble(bubbleName, createBubbleData?): Promise<Bubble> Create a new bubble; This API also sends BubbleServiceEvents.ON_NEW_BUBBLE_CREATED event Parameters • bubbleName: string The name of the bubble • createBubbleData?: CreateBubbleData The name of the bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> demoteAllUsers() demoteAllUsers(bubble): Promise<Bubble> Demote all moderators to Users role. API available only for the owner of the bubble Parameters • bubble: Bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> getAllServerBubbles() getAllServerBubbles(status): Promise<void> Load all bubble from server in a given status Parameters • status: string values: 'invited', 'accepted','unsubscribed' Returns Promise<void> getBubble() getBubble(bubbleRef): Promise<Bubble> Async method -which get get a bubble. The bubble is first search in service cache then server side. Parameters • bubbleRef: string The bubble dbId or bubble JID Returns Promise<Bubble> getBubbleFromCache() getBubbleFromCache(id): Bubble Synchronous method used to get a existing bubble from the cache Parameters • id: string Should be the bubble id or dbId Returns Bubble getBubbleInvitations() getBubbleInvitations(): Bubble[] Return an array of all bubbles where user is currently invited to participants (in "invited" state) Returns Bubble[] getBubbles() getBubbles(): Bubble[] Return an array of all bubbles already in the cache Returns Bubble[] getBubblesWithActiveConference() getBubblesWithActiveConference(): Bubble[] Return an array of all bubbles with an active conference at the moment Returns Bubble[] getMyBubbles() getMyBubbles(): Bubble[] Return an array of all MY bubbles Returns Bubble[] isStarted() isStarted(): boolean Return the service start state Returns boolean promoteAllUsers() promoteAllUsers(bubble): Promise<Bubble> Promote all users to Moderator role. API available only for the owner of the bubble Parameters • bubble: Bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> searchBubbles() searchBubbles(searchPattern, options?): Promise<BubbleSearchResult[]> This API allows to search Rainbow bubbles that match a search criteria applied on some name properties such as the name of the bubble or the names of bubble participants for example. One or more name properties can be optionally specified to define the scope of the search. If no scope is specified, the search is performed by default on the name of the bubble only. It is also possible to optionally specify how the list of bubbles returned as results should be sorted. By default, the bubbles list will be sorted by bubble name. Parameters • searchPattern: string The search criteria • options?: SearchBubblesOptions Options to specify the scope of the search and how the results are to be returned. Returns Promise<BubbleSearchResult[]> subscribe() subscribe(handler, eventNames?): Subscription Subscribe to the invitations updates; All events send to the callback are of type RBEvent Parameters • handler • eventNames?: BubbleServiceEvents | BubbleServiceEvents[] Returns Subscription Sur cette pageMethodscreateBubble()ParametersReturnsdemoteAllUsers()ParametersReturnsgetAllServerBubbles()ParametersReturnsgetBubble()ParametersReturnsgetBubbleFromCache()ParametersReturnsgetBubbleInvitations()ReturnsgetBubbles()ReturnsgetBubblesWithActiveConference()ReturnsgetMyBubbles()ReturnsisStarted()ReturnspromoteAllUsers()ParametersReturnssearchBubbles()ParametersReturnssubscribe()ParametersReturnsCe contenu vous a-t-il été utile ?OuiNonFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions légalesContrat de servicesContrat de développeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur

content: DocumentationWebv2 > lts > api > Bubbles > interfaces > BubbleSettingsRainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / BubbleSettings Interface: BubbleSettings This interface defines the settings that can be send to the updateSettings bubble API Properties autoAcceptInvitation? optional autoAcceptInvitation: boolean Invited users will be auto-added in the bubble autoRegister? optional autoRegister: string A user can create a bubble and not have to register users. He can share instead a public link also called 'public URL'(users public link). According with autoRegister value, if another person uses the link to join the bubble: autoRegister = 'unlock': If this user is not yet registered inside this bubble, he is automatically included with the status 'accepted' and join the bubble. autoRegister = 'lock': If this user is not yet registered inside this bubble, he can't access to the bubble. So that he can't join the bubble. autoRegister = 'unlock_ack' (value not authorized yet): If this user is not yet registered inside this bubble, he can't access to the bubble waiting for the bubble's owner acknowledgment. disableTimeStats? optional disableTimeStats: boolean if TRUE, in case of conference in this bubble/bubble, the talking time stats will be disabled includeAllPhoneNumbers? optional includeAllPhoneNumbers: boolean Indicates if user chooses to include all Dial In phone numbers muteUponEntry? optional muteUponEntry: boolean In case of conference in this bubble/bubble, all participants will be muted upon join name? optional name: string Avatar image for the bubble playEntryTone? optional playEntryTone: boolean In case of conference in this bubble/bubble, a local tone should be played when user joins. topic? optional topic: string The bubble description Sur cette pageCe contenu vous a-t-il été utile ?OuiNonFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions légalesContrat de servicesContrat de développeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur

excerpt: DocumentationCreateBubbleDataLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / CreateBubbleData Interface: CreateBubbleData The CreateBubbleData interface describes the
content: DocumentationCreateBubbleDataLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / CreateBubbleData Interface: CreateBubbleData The CreateBubbleData interface describes the data that can be send to the create bubble API Example const data = { "topic": "my bubble topic", "createConversation": true, "autoAcceptInvitation": true } createBubble("my bubble name", data); Properties autoAcceptInvitation? optional autoAcceptInvitation: boolean When set to true, allows to automatically add participants in the bubble (default behavior is that participants need to accept the bubble invitation first before being a member of this bubble) Default : FALSE bubbleAvatar? optional bubbleAvatar: any Avatar image for the bubble contacts? optional contacts: Contact[] List of contacts that we want to invite to the bubble disableTimeStats? optional disableTimeStats: boolean If TRUE, in case of conference in this bubble the talking time stats will be disabled Default : FALSE guestEmails? optional guestEmails: string[] List of emails that we want to invite to the bubble (will receive an invitation email) muteUponEntry? optional muteUponEntry: boolean In case of conference in this bubble, all participants will be muted upon join Default : FALSE noConversation? optional noConversation: boolean If TRUE, the server will NOT create a conversation for this bubble Default : FALSE noEntryTone? optional noEntryTone: boolean In case of conference in this bubble, a local tone should be played when user joins. Default : TRUE noHistory? optional noHistory: boolean If TRUE, the old history will NOT be shown to new users Default : FALSE privilege? optional privilege: BubbleUserPrivilege Add optional body parameter privilege ('user', 'moderator'). By default, all users get the simple 'user' privilege. Using 'privilege' parameter all invited users may have the same privilege in this bulk. topic? optional topic: string The bubble description Sur cette pageExamplePropertiesautoAcceptInvitation?bubbleAvatar?contacts?disableTimeStats?guestEmails?muteUponEntry?noConversation?noEntryTone?noHistory?privilege?topic?Ce contenu vous a-t-il été utile ?OuiNonFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions légalesContrat de servicesContrat de développeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur

content: DocumentationSearchBubblesOptionsLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / SearchBubblesOptions Interface: SearchBubblesOptions Properties scope? optional scope: SearchBubblesScope[] Options to specify the scope of the search, i.e. the 'name' properties to be used as scope for the search The name properties that can be specified are: The name of the bubble The name of tag(s) set for the bubble The name of bubble participants. excerpt: DocumentationCallLogServiceEventsLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogServiceEvents Enumeration: CallLogServiceEvents CallLog service events send to
content: DocumentationCallLogServiceEventsLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogServiceEvents Enumeration: CallLogServiceEvents CallLog service events send to other services Can listen to it via CallLogService.subscribe() API Events ON_CALLLOG_MISSEDCALLS_COUNTER_UPDATED ON_CALLLOG_MISSEDCALLS_COUNTER_UPDATED: "ON_CALLLOG_MISSEDCALLS_COUNTER_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when the counter of missed calls has been updated. Event Data counter - The number of missed calls ON_CALLLOG_TOTAL_NUMBER_UPDATED ON_CALLLOG_TOTAL_NUMBER_UPDATED: "ON_CALLLOG_TOTAL_NUMBER_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when the total number of call logs for the connected user has been updated. Event Data counter - The total number of call logs ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED: "ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when the call log history has been updated in one of the following ways: Reception of a new call log from the server (in the form of a notification, and not in response to an explicit fetch request). User request to delete call logs. This covers cases of deletion of a specific call log, all call logs associated with a user, or the user's entire call log history. This event contains no data, the current call logs history have to be retrieved by using the getCallLogs() API. content: DocumentationCallLogTypeLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogType Enumeration: CallLogType Call type Enumeration Members CONFERENCE CONFERENCE: "conference" A call is considered a "conference" when it involves more than 2 participants. TELEPHONE TELEPHONE: "telephone" A call is considered "telephonic" when the party initiating the call has explicitly used a number (by dialing or selecting it) to reach the other party. WEBRTC WEBRTC: "webrtc" A call is considered "webrtc" when it initiated between 2 users using a Rainbow client (Web, Desktop or Mobile) A "webrtc" call can be considered as an Internet call. content: DocumentationCallLogLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLog Interface: CallLog Properties callSubject? optional readonly callSubject: string The subject of the call calledNumber readonly calledNumber: string The number of the called party date readonly date: Date The date of the call direction readonly direction: CallDirection The call direction duration readonly duration: number The call duration in milliseconds id readonly id: string The unique identifier of the call log read readonly read: boolean The reading status, indicates if the call log has been marked as read or not. state readonly state: string The call state: "answered": Refers to an answered call with a conversation established and this, regardless of direction (Incoming or outgoing). "missed": Refers to an unanswered call, regardless of direction (Incoming or outgoing). "forwarded": Refers to an incoming call which has been forwarded to the connected user (who was not the initial destination). type readonly type: CallLogType The call type user readonly user: User The associated user representing the other party (as caller or callee) of the call userCallbackNumber? optional readonly userCallbackNumber: string The number used to call back a Rainbow user if this one has not shared the private profile fields, including their telephone numbers. As a result, there is no telephone number visible (so usable) in the user's associated contact object. This number has been received as call information and is linked to the current call log only. title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationCallLogServiceLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogService Interface: CallLogService Methods deleteAllCallLogs() deleteAllCallLogs(): Pr
content: DocumentationCallLogServiceLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogService Interface: CallLogService Methods deleteAllCallLogs() deleteAllCallLogs(): Promise<any> Delete all the call logs history of the connected user A ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED event is sent afterwards at the completion of the operation to notify about the call logs history update. Returns Promise<any> deleteCallLog() deleteCallLog(callLog): Promise<any> Delete the call log specified by its object instance A ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED event is sent afterwards at the completion of the operation to notify about the call logs history update. Parameters • callLog: CallLog The call log instance to delete Returns Promise<any> deleteCallLogsForUser() deleteCallLogsForUser(user): Promise<any> Delete all call logs associated with a user A ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED event is sent afterwards at the completion of the operation to notify about the call logs history update. Parameters • user: User Returns Promise<any> getCallLogs() getCallLogs(): Promise<CallLog[]> Get the current content of the call logs history. The request can be made at any time to retrieve the call logs already known by the Call Log service. It is also advisable to make this request when an 'ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED' event has been received notifying you that the call logs history has been updated following an operation such as the reception of a brand new call log, the modification (e.g., marking as read) or the deletion of existing call log(s). Returns Promise<CallLog[]> Returns a Promise with an array of the call logs already known by the Call Log service getCallLogsCounter() getCallLogsCounter(): number Return the number total of call logs available for the connected user Returns number getMissedCallsCounter() getMissedCallsCounter(): number Returns the number total of missed calls. Missed call is a call with the following properties: state is 'missed', direction is 'incoming' and read flag is 'false'. This API can be called before the first call logs are retrieved, i.e. before the initialization step. Returns number getNextCallLogs() getNextCallLogs(number): Promise<CallLog[]> Get additional call logs. The number of additional call logs to be returned can be specified in the request Parameters • number: number (optional) Number of additional call logs to get. This parameter is optional and set by default to 100. The allowed range of values is [1..250]. If the value provided is greater, the maximum value will be used. If the value is 0 or less, the request will be rejected and an error thrown. Returns Promise<CallLog[]> Returns a Promise with an array of the call logs already known by the Call Log service and the newly retrieved. Throws Error - In the event of the specified parameter is invalid. initCallLogs() initCallLogs(number): Promise<CallLog[]> Initializes the CallLog service for the user by returning the most recent call logs. The number of call logs to be returned can optionnaly be specified in the request Additional call logs have to be retrieved furthermore via the API 'getNextCallLogs'. Parameters • number: number (optional) Number of call logs to retrieve at initialization step. This parameter is optional and set by default to 100. The allowed range of values is [1..250]. If the value provided is greater, the maximum value will be used. If the value is 0 or less, the request will be rejected and an error thrown. Returns Promise<CallLog[]> Returns a Promise with an array of the first retrieved call logs Throws Error - In the event of the specified parameter is invalid. isInitialized() isInitialized(): boolean Indicates whether the CallLog Service has been initialized or not. If this is not the case, no call log has yet been retrieved. Returns boolean True if the CallLog Service has been intitialized; False otherwise. markAllCallsLogsAsRead() markAllCallsLogsAsRead(): void Mark all call logs already known by the Call Log service as read This concerns the call logs fetched from server during the initialization step and through additional fetch requests. Returns void markCallLogAsRead() markCallLogAsRead(callLog): void Mark a call log item specified by its object instance as read Parameters • callLog: CallLog The call log instance to mark as read Returns void subscribe() subscribe(callback, eventNames?): Subscription Subscribe to the CallLog updates, all events are of RBEvent Parameters • callback The callback function that will be called when events are received • eventNames?: CallLogServiceEvents | CallLogServiceEvents[] (optional) array of event to listen Returns Subscription Returns RxJS Subscription Sur cette pageMethodsdeleteAllCallLogs()ReturnsdeleteCallLog()ParametersReturnsdeleteCallLogsForUser()ParametersReturnsgetCallLogs()ReturnsgetCallLogsCounter()ReturnsgetMissedCallsCounter()ReturnsgetNextCallLogs()ParametersReturnsThrowsinitCallLogs()ParametersReturnsThrowsisInitialized()ReturnsmarkAllCallsLogsAsRead()ReturnsmarkCallLogAsRead()Paramete

excerpt: DocumentationCallEventsLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallEvents Enumeration: CallEvents Call events send to other services Can listen to it via Call.su
content: DocumentationCallEventsLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallEvents Enumeration: CallEvents Call events send to other services Can listen to it via Call.subscribe() API. Events ON_CALL_CAPABILITIES_UPDATED ON_CALL_CAPABILITIES_UPDATED: "ON_CALL_CAPABILITIES_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when the call capabilities have been updated. The new call capabilities can be retrieved via the 'capabilities' property. ON_CALL_MEDIA_UPDATED ON_CALL_MEDIA_UPDATED: "ON_CALL_MEDIA_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when there have been changes in the media used by the local or the remote user. By change we mean the addition or removal of a media (Video/Sharing) for the current call. ON_CALL_MUTE_CHANGE ON_CALL_MUTE_CHANGE: "ON_CALL_MUTE_CHANGE" This RBEvent is sent when the status of the mute of the call (On or Off) has changed. The new mute status can be retrieved via the 'isMuted' property. ON_CALL_NETWORK_QUALITY_CHANGE ON_CALL_NETWORK_QUALITY_CHANGE: "ON_CALL_NETWORK_QUALITY_CHANGE" This RBEvent is sent when during a call, the network quality has changed. Event Data data - The current network quality for the call ON_CALL_STATUS_CHANGE ON_CALL_STATUS_CHANGE: "ON_CALL_STATUS_CHANGE" This RBEvent is sent when the status of the call (from a telephone point of view) has changed. The new call status can be retrieved via the 'callStatus' property. ON_CALL_UPDATED_EVENT ON_CALL_UPDATED_EVENT: "ON_CALL_UPDATED_EVENT" This RBEvent is sent when when the call has evolved and as a result some of its properties, such as its status, have been updated. content: DocumentationCallStatusLTS release 5.0.0Publiée le 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallStatus Enumeration: CallStatus The possible status of the call (e.g. dialing, active, releasing...) Enumeration Members ACTIVE ACTIVE: "ACTIVE" Active call ANSWERING ANSWERING: "ANSWERING" Call is being answered CONNECTING CONNECTING: "CONNECTING" Trying to connect / reconnect the call DIALING DIALING: "DIALING" In dialing ENDED ENDED: "ENDED" Call Cleared ERROR ERROR: "ERROR" Call error HOLD HOLD: "HOLD" Call on hold by local party PUT_ON_HOLD PUT_ON_HOLD: "PUT_ON_HOLD" Call put on hold by the distant party QUEUED_INCOMMING QUEUED_INCOMMING: "QUEUED_INCOMMING" In queue (user side) QUEUED_OUTGOING QUEUED_OUTGOING: "QUEUED_OUTGOING" In queue (recipient side) RELEASING RELEASING: "RELEASING" Call is clearing RINGING_INCOMMING RINGING_INCOMMING: "RINGING_INCOMMING" Call in ringing (user side) RINGING_OUTGOING RINGING_OUTGOING: "RINGING_OUTGOING" Call in ringing (recipient side) Sur cette pageEnumeration MembersACTIVEANSWERINGCONNECTINGDIALINGENDEDERRORHOLDPUT_ON_HOLDQUEUED_INCOMMINGQUEUED_OUTGOINGRELEASINGRINGING_INCOMMINGRINGING_OUTGOINGCe contenu vous a-t-il été utile ?OuiNonFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions légalesContrat de servicesContrat de développeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur
